gameData.description: Creatures from the animal kingdom, including mammals, insects, and marine life.

easy.hint: A minute bug that feeds by sucking sap from plants.
A mammal whose forelimbs form webbed wings, making them the only mammals naturally capable of true and sustained flight.
A large, heavy, mammal that walks on the soles of its feet, with thick fur and a very short tail.
A small domesticated carnivorous mammal with soft fur, a short snout, and retractable claws.
A bivalve mollusk with a shell of two equal halves.
A venomous snake of a family (Elapidae) that is native to Asia and Africa and is characterized by a hood of skin which it can expand.
The common name for the demersal fish genus Gadus, belonging to the family Gadidae.
A hard stony substance secreted by certain marine coelenterates as an external skeleton, typically forming large reefs in warm seas.
A crustacean with a broad carapace, stalked eyes, and five pairs of legs, the first pair of which are modified as pincers.
A large perching bird with mostly glossy black plumage, a stout bill, and a loud, harsh call.
A type of dog native to Australia.
A domesticated carnivorous mammal that typically has a long snout, an acute sense of smell, and a barking, howling, or whining voice.
A stocky bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, feeding on seeds or fruit.
A large bird of prey with a massive hooked bill and long broad wings, known for its keen sight.
A snakelike fish with a slender elongated body and poorly developed fins, proverbial for its slipperiness.
A seed-eating songbird that typically has a stout conical bill.
A small wingless jumping insect that feeds on the blood of mammals and birds.
Insects of the order Diptera, the name being derived from the Greek δι- di- 'two', and πτερόν pteron 'wing'.
A carnivorous mammal of the dog family with a pointed snout and a bushy tail, proverbial for its cunning.
A small two-winged fly that resembles a mosquito.
A large waterbird with a long neck, short legs, webbed feet, and a broad bill.
A bird of prey with broad rounded wings and a long tail, typically taking prey by surprise with a short chase.
A domesticated perissodactyl mammal, used for riding, racing, and to carry and pull loads.
A carnivorous mammal found in Africa and Asia.
A bird of the crow family with brightly colored plumage.
An arboreal herbivorous marsupial native to Australia.
A small shrimplike planktonic crustacean of the open seas, eaten by a number of larger animals, notably the baleen whales.
A small ground-dwelling songbird, typically with brown streaky plumage and a crest.
An arboreal primate with a pointed snout and typically a long tail, found only in Madagascar.
This large cat is known as the 'king of the jungle'.
A domesticated South American camelid, widely used as a meat and pack animal by Andean cultures since the Pre-Columbian era.
A small, wingless, parasitic insect that lives on the skin of mammals and birds.
A large long-tailed parrot with brightly colored plumage.
A large deer with palmate antlers, a sloping back, and a drooping muzzle, native to northern Eurasia and North America.
A paraphyletic group of insects that includes all members of the order Lepidoptera that are not butterflies.
A giraffid artiodactyl mammal native to the northeast of the Democratic Republic of the Congo in Central Africa.
A domesticated animal raised for its meat, such as bacon and pork.
A small, short-tailed game bird.
A large heavily built crow with mainly black plumage.
A carnivorous aquatic mammal with a streamlined body and feet developed as flippers, that returns to land to breed or rest.
A domesticated ruminant animal, raised for its wool, meat, and milk.
A mammal of the family Mephitidae.
A long, limbless reptile that has no eyelids, a short tail, and jaws that are capable of considerable extension.
An elongated, fast-swimming cephalopod with ten arms (technically, eight arms and two long tentacles), typically able to change color.
A tall long-legged wading bird with a long heavy bill and typically with white and black plumage.
A large waterbird with a long flexible neck, short legs, webbed feet, a broad bill, and typically all-white plumage.
A minute black insect with a slender body and narrow, fringed wings.
A small arachnid that attaches itself to the skin of an animal and sucks its blood.
A certain kind of frog, particularly a number of species in the family Bufonidae, that are characterized by dry, leathery skin, short legs, and large bumps covering the parotoid glands.
A winged insect which is neither a bee nor an ant.
A very large marine mammal with a streamlined hairless body, a horizontal tail fin, and a blowhole on top of the head for breathing.
A wild carnivorous mammal which is the largest member of the dog family, living and hunting in packs.
An African equine with distinctive black-and-white striped coats.

normal.hint: A medium-sized, burrowing, nocturnal mammal native to Africa.
A very large seabird.
A large reptile in the Crocodylia order in the genus Alligator of the family Alligatoridae.
A species of South American camelid, similar to, and often confused with, the llama.
A small, common forage fish of the family Engraulidae.
A sedentary marine coelenterate with a columnar body that bears a ring of stinging tentacles around the mouth.
A family of ray-finned fish, Pomacanthidae, found on shallow reefs in the tropical Atlantic, Indian, and mostly western Pacific oceans.
A eusocial insect of the family Formicidae and, along with the related wasps and bees, belong to the order Hymenoptera.
A herbivorous mammal belonging to the family Bovidae.
A New World placental mammal with a leathery armor shell.
A large Old World monkey with a long, doglike muzzle and large canine teeth.
A carnivorous mammal in the family Mustelidae.
A marine crustacean with an external shell, which attaches itself permanently to a variety of surfaces.
A large, predatory, ray-finned fish known for its fearsome appearance and ferocious behaviour.
A large, primarily nocturnal, semiaquatic rodent.
A winged insect closely related to wasps and ants, known for their role in pollination and, in the case of the best-known bee species, the European honey bee, for producing honey and beeswax.
A group of insects that form the order Coleoptera, in the superorder Endopterygota.
A humpbacked shaggy-haired wild ox native to North America and Europe.
The largest animal on Earth, a marine mammal.
A North American thrush, the male of which has a blue head, back, and wings.
A primarily diurnal insect of the order Lepidoptera, which also includes moths.
An even-toed ungulate within the genus Camelus that bears distinctive fatty deposits known as 'humps' on its back.
A mainly African finch with a melodious song, typically having yellowish-green plumage.
The largest living rodent in the world.
A New World finch, the male of which is mainly bright red.
A North American thrush with grey plumage and a black cap and tail, noted for its catlike mewing call.
A distinctive and highly specialized clade of Old World lizards with 202 species described as of June 2015.
A large cat native to Africa and central Iran.
A North American titmouse.
A domesticated fowl, raised for its eggs and meat.
A species of great ape native to the forest and savannah of tropical Africa.
A small rodent native to the Andes mountains in South America.
A large insect with long transparent wings, found chiefly in warm countries.
A small, brightly colored fish that lives in symbiosis with sea anemones.
Insects of the order Blattodea, which also includes termites.
A large diving bird with a long neck, long hooked bill, and dark plumage.
A domesticated bovine animal, raised for its milk, meat, and leather.
A canine native to North America.
A tall, long-legged, long-necked bird, typically with white or grey plumage and often with a patch of bare red skin on the head.
A nocturnal freshwater crustacean that resembles a small lobster and inhabits streams and rivers.
An insect belonging to the order Orthoptera.
A large semiaquatic reptile that lives throughout the tropics in Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia.
A hoofed grazing or browsing animal, with branched bony antlers that are shed annually and typically borne only by the male.
A highly intelligent marine mammal known for its playful behavior.
An insect belonging to the order Odonata, infraorder Anisoptera.
A waterbird with a broad blunt bill, short legs, webbed feet, and a waddling gait.
A small insect with a pair of pincers at its rear end.
An egg-laying mammal native to Australia and New Guinea.
The largest land animal, known for its long trunk and large ears.
A small, carnivorous mammal.
A tall wading bird with mainly pink or scarlet plumage and long legs and neck.
A tailless amphibian with a short-bodied, stout build, prominent eyes, and long, powerful hind limbs adapted for leaping.
A swift antelope found in Africa and Asia.
A small lizard of a large family found in warm climates, having suction pads on its feet that enable it to climb on smooth vertical surfaces.
A small, slender, long-armed ape of the family Hylobatidae.
The tallest living terrestrial animal, known for its extremely long neck.
A hardy domesticated ruminant animal, raised for its milk, meat, and hair.
A brightly colored finch with a yellow patch on each wing.
A small, orange-colored freshwater fish, often kept as a pet in a bowl or aquarium.
A large ape native to the forests of central Sub-Saharan Africa.
A large predatory fish found in coastal waters of all major oceans.
A finch with a massive bill.
A small, stout-bodied rodent with large cheek pouches, often kept as a pet.
A spiny mammal of the subfamily Erinaceinae.
A large fish-eating wading bird with long legs, a long S-shaped neck, and a long pointed bill.
A forage fish, mostly belonging to the family of Clupeidae.
A flying insect known for producing honey and pollinating flowers.
A bird with a massive bill, typically having a casque on the upper mandible.
A large predatory wasp, typically having a brown and yellow-striped body.
A genus of herbivorous lizards that are native to tropical areas of Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Caribbean.
A medium-sized omnivorous mammal of the subtribe Canina.
A free-swimming marine animal with a gelatinous umbrella-shaped bell and trailing tentacles.
A marsupial from Australia, known for its powerful hind legs and pouch.
A large, typically green, long-horned grasshopper.
A small falcon that hovers with rapidly beating wings.
A brightly colored bird with a long, sharp beak, found near water and feeding on fish.
A long-winged bird of prey with a deeply forked tail.
A species of lizard found in the Indonesian islands of Komodo, Rinca, Flores, and Gili Motang.
A slender insect with delicate, net-veined wings.
A small beetle with a round, often brightly colored, body.
A small bug that sucks sap from plants.
A large cat native to Africa and Asia.
A reptile that typically has a long body and tail, four legs, and a tapering snout.
A large marine crustacean with a cylindrical body, stalked eyes, and the first of its five pairs of limbs modified as pincers.
A common name applied to a number of different species of pelagic fish, mostly from the family Scombridae.
A long-tailed crow with boldly marked (or entirely black) plumage and a raucous call.
A large aquatic plant-eating mammal with a tapering body, no hind limbs, and a broad, flat tail.
A large West African baboon with a red and blue face, a yellow beard, and a red rump.
A slender predatory insect with a triangular head that waits motionless for prey with its large forelegs folded as if in prayer.
An aquatic insect with a very short adult life.
A small carnivoran belonging to the mongoose family.
Famous for its long-distance seasonal migration.
A small terrestrial carnivorous mammal belonging to the family Herpestidae.
A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
A group of about 3,500 species of small insects within the family Culicidae (from the Latin culex meaning 'gnat').
A bivalve mollusk with a dark elongated shell, found attached to rocks and other fixed objects in shallow coastal waters.
A small Arctic whale, the male of which has a long forward-pointing spirally twisted tusk developed from one of its teeth.
A salamander in the subfamily Pleurodelinae.
A small European thrush with drab brownish plumage, noted for the melodious song of the male, heard especially at night.
A wild cat native to the southwestern United States, Mexico, and Central and South America.
A soft-bodied, eight-limbed mollusc of the order Octopoda.
A marsupial of the order Didelphimorphia endemic to the Americas.
A great ape native to the rainforests of Indonesia and Malaysia, known for its long arms and reddish-brown hair.
A fast-running African flightless bird with a long neck, long legs, and two toes on each foot.
A carnivorous mammal in the subfamily Lutrinae.
A nocturnal bird of prey with large forward-facing eyes surrounded by facial disks, a hooked beak, and typically a loud call.
A bivalve mollusk with a rough irregular shell, several kinds of which are eaten (especially raw) as a delicacy and may be farmed for food or pearls.
A bear native to south central China, known for its black and white coat and diet of bamboo.
A brightly colored bird, often kept as a pet, that is able to mimic human speech.
A short-tailed game bird with mainly brown plumage.
A male peafowl, which has a crested head and a very long ornate tail that has eyelike markings and can be erected and fanned out in display.
A large waterbird with a long bill and a large throat pouch for scooping up fish.
A flightless bird that lives in the Southern Hemisphere, primarily in Antarctica.
A large long-tailed game bird, the male of which has brightly colored plumage.
A stout seed- or fruit-eating bird with a small head, short legs, and a cooing voice, typically having a grey and white plumage.
A member of a family of omnivorous freshwater fish that live in South American rivers, floodplains, lakes and reservoirs.
A semiaquatic egg-laying mammal endemic to eastern Australia, including Tasmania.
A large bear native to the Arctic Circle, known for its white fur.
A rodent with a coat of sharp spines, or quills, that protect against predators.
A marine crustacean that resembles a large shrimp.
A genus of constricting snakes in the Pythonidae family native to the tropics and subtropics of the Eastern Hemisphere.
A burrowing, plant-eating mammal with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.
A medium-sized mammal native to North America.
A mammal native to the eastern Himalayas and southwestern China.
A member of any of the five extant species of odd-toed ungulates in the family Rhinocerotidae.
A fast-running bird of the cuckoo family, found in arid country from the southern US to Central America.
A small insectivorous songbird with a red breast, found in Europe, Asia, and North America.

A group of amphibians typically characterized by a lizard-like appearance, with slender bodies, blunt snouts, short limbs projecting at right angles to the body, and the presence of a tail in both larvae and adults.
A large edible fish that is a popular game fish, much prized for its pink flesh. Salmon are native to tributaries of the North Atlantic (genus Salmo) and Pacific Ocean (genus Oncorhynchus).
A wading bird with a long bill and typically long legs, nesting on the ground near water.
A small, oily forage fish.
A bivalve mollusk with a fan-shaped shell, the large adductor muscle of which is edible.
A reptile that lives in the ocean and has a bony or cartilaginous shell.
A large seal of the northern Pacific, the male of which has a mane on the neck and shoulders.
A marine echinoderm that has a spherical or flattened shell covered in mobile spines.
A bird with long wings and typically white and grey plumage, living near the sea and feeding on fish and other marine animals.
A small free-swimming crustacean with an elongated body, typically marine and frequently of commercial importance as food.
A small, wingless insect with a silvery-grey body.
A common Eurasian lark noted for its melodious song, delivered by the male in hovering flight.
A medium-sized mammal belonging to the families Megalonychidae and Bradypodidae.
A small bird with a brown and grey plumage.
A primitive sedentary aquatic invertebrate with a soft porous body that is typically supported by a framework of fibers or calcareous or siliceous spicules.
A marine echinoderm with five or more radiating arms.
A gregarious Old World songbird with a straight bill, typically with dark, glossy plumage.
A group of sea rays, which are cartilaginous fish related to sharks.
An aquatic insect with a flattened body and long antennae.
A small bird with a forked tail and long pointed wings, noted for its agile flight.
A large, predatory fish characterized by a long, flat, pointed bill.
A small American songbird, the male of which has brightly colored plumage.
A large, herbivorous mammal, similar in shape to a pig, with a short, prehensile nose trunk.
A small insect that lives in large colonies and feeds on wood.
A small or medium-sized songbird, typically having a brown back, spotted breast, and loud song.
The largest cat species, known for its distinctive orange coat with dark vertical stripes.
A tropical American fruit-eating bird with a massive bill and brightly colored plumage.
A species of freshwater fish in the salmon family Salmonidae.
A saltwater fish that belongs to the tribe Thunnini, a subgrouping of the Scombridae (mackerel) family.
A large mainly domesticated game bird, native to North America, farmed for its flesh.
A slow-moving reptile, enclosed in a bony or leathery shell, that can live on land or in water.

A large bird of prey with the head and neck more or less bare of feathers, feeding chiefly on carrion and reputed to gather with others in anticipation of the death of a sick or injured animal or person.
A slender-bodied songbird with a long tail that is frequently wagged up and down.
A small or mid-sized macropod native to Australia and New Guinea.
A large flippered marine mammal with a discontinuous distribution about the North Pole in the Arctic Ocean and subarctic seas of the Northern Hemisphere.
A wild member of the pig family found in grassland, savanna, and woodland in sub-Saharan Africa.
A finch-like songbird that builds an elaborately woven nest.
An insect that lives in a silken web that it spins from its forelegs.
A short-legged, muscular quadrupedal marsupial that is native to Australia.
A bird with a strong bill and a stiff tail, that climbs tree trunks to find insects and drums on the wood to mark territory.
A small short-winged songbird.
A long-haired domesticated bovid found throughout the Himalayan region of the Indian subcontinent, the Tibetan Plateau and as far north as Mongolia and Russia.

difficult.hint: A species of large, heavy-bodied snake that is frequently kept and bred in captivity.
A group of insects belonging to the suborder Caelifera.
A large African game bird with slate-colored, white-spotted plumage and a loud, harsh call.
A large, semiaquatic mammal native to sub-Saharan Africa.
A small bird known for its ability to hover in mid-air by rapidly flapping its wings.
A long-tailed American songbird with a varied song that often imitates the calls of other birds.
A carnivorous marsupial of the family Dasyuridae, now found in the wild only on the Australian island state of Tasmania.
An insect with a long, slender, twiglike body.

easy.hint: A salt (the sodium salt of boric acid), a soft, colorless, crystalline mineral.
A group of minerals whose outstanding physical characteristic is that individual mica crystals can easily be split into extremely thin elastic plates.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula NaCl.
An alloy of iron and carbon, and sometimes other elements.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula H₂O.

normal.hint: An alloy of mercury with another metal.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula NH₃.
A chemical product that is used industrially and domestically to remove color from a fabric or fiber or to clean or to remove stains in a process called bleaching.
An alloy of copper and zinc, in proportions which can be varied to achieve varying mechanical and electrical properties.

An alloy consisting primarily of copper, commonly with about 12–12.5% tin and often with the addition of other metals (such as aluminium, manganese, nickel or zinc) and sometimes non-metals or metalloids such as arsenic, phosphorus or silicon.
A carbonate mineral and the most stable polymorph of calcium carbonate (CaCO₃).
An aromatic organic compound with the molecular formula C₆H₅OH.
The chemical element with the symbol C and atomic number 6.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula CO₂.
An inorganic compound with the formula KOH.
The chemical compound with the formula NaNO₃.
The chemical element with the symbol Cl and atomic number 17.
A chemical compound with the formula CHCl₃, it is a colorless, sweet-smelling, dense liquid that is produced on a large scale as a precursor to PTFE.
The chemical element with the symbol Cu and atomic number 29.
The potassium acid salt of tartaric acid.
An anhydrous carbonate mineral composed of calcium magnesium carbonate, ideally CaMg(CO₃)₂.
The solid form of carbon dioxide.
A trade name for one of the earliest types of age-hardenable aluminium alloys.
A naturally occurring alloy of gold and silver, with trace amounts of copper and other metals.
An inorganic salt containing magnesium, sulfur and oxygen, with the formula MgSO₄.
A chemical compound, a simple alcohol with the chemical formula C₂H₆O.
A group of rock-forming tectosilicate minerals that make up as much as 60% of the Earth's crust.
The natural mineral form of lead(II) sulfide (PbS). It is the most important ore of lead and an important source of silver.
A simple polyol compound. It is a colorless, odorless, viscous liquid that is sweet-tasting and non-toxic.
The chemical element with the symbol Au and atomic number 79.
A soft sulfate mineral composed of calcium sulfate dihydrate, with the chemical formula CaSO₄·2H₂O.
The mineral form of sodium chloride (NaCl), commonly known as rock salt.
The chemical element with the symbol He and atomic number 2.
The mineral form of iron(III) oxide (Fe₂O₃), one of several iron oxides.
The chemical element with the symbol H and atomic number 1.
The chemical element with the symbol Fe and atomic number 26.
A carbonate sedimentary rock that is often composed of the skeletal fragments of marine organisms such as coral, foraminifera, and molluscs.
An inorganic compound with the formula NaOH. It is a white solid ionic compound consisting of sodium cations Na⁺ and hydroxide anions OH⁻.
A rock mineral and one of the main iron ores, with the chemical formula Fe₃O₄.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula CH₄.
A chemical compound with the chemical formula CH₄.
A colorless inorganic chemical system with the formula H₂O:HCl.
The chemical element with the symbol N and atomic number 7.
The chemical element with the symbol O and atomic number 8.
A malleable metal alloy, traditionally between 85 and 99% tin, with the remainder consisting of copper, antimony, bismuth and lead.
An iron sulfide with the chemical formula FeS₂. This mineral's metallic luster and pale brass-yellow hue give it a superficial resemblance to gold, hence its well-known nickname of 'fool's gold'.
A hard, crystalline mineral composed of silicon and oxygen atoms.
A widely used chemical compound. It is a white, caustic, alkaline, crystalline solid at room temperature.
The mineral form of potassium nitrate, KNO₃.
The chemical element with the symbol Ag and atomic number 47.
The chemical element with the symbol Na and atomic number 11.
A fusible metal alloy used to create a permanent bond between metal workpieces.
The generic name for sweet-tasting, soluble carbohydrates, many of which are used in food.
A chemical compound with the formula C₆H₂(NO₂)₃CH₃.
An aqueous solution of acetic acid and trace chemicals that may include flavorings.

difficult.hint: A chemical compound with the formula NaHCO₃.
The chemical compound with the chemical formula CuSO₄. This salt exists as a series of compounds that differ in their degree of hydration.
The decahydrate form of sodium sulfate, Na₂SO₄·10H₂O.
The chemical compound with the formula FeSO₄.
A form of water that contains a larger than normal amount of the hydrogen isotope deuterium.
An inorganic compound with the formula Na₂S₂O₃.
A chemical compound, an oxide of nitrogen with the formula N₂O.
An inorganic compound with the chemical formula Mg(OH)₂.
The inorganic compound with the formula (NH₄)₂Fe(SO₄)₂·6H₂O.
A mineral acid composed of the elements sulfur, oxygen and hydrogen, with molecular formula H₂SO₄.
A quick-setting gypsum plaster consisting of a fine white powder, which hardens when moistened and allowed to dry.
A chemical compound: the potassium double sulfate of aluminium.
A chemical element with the symbol Hg and atomic number 80.
A double salt of tartaric acid first prepared by an apothecary, Pierre Seignette, of La Rochelle, France.
An inorganic compound with the formula NH₄Cl.
An inorganic compound with the chemical formula Ca(OH)₂.
A group of ferrous alloys that contain a minimum of approximately 11% chromium, a composition that prevents the iron from rusting and provides heat-resistant properties.
The inorganic compound with the formula Na₂CO₃ and its various hydrates.
The inorganic compound with the formula ZnSO₄.

gameData.description: Major cities and capitals from around the world.

easy.hint: The capital of Nigeria.
The capital of Jordan.
The capital of Samoa.
The capital of Switzerland.
The capital of Egypt, famous for the nearby Giza pyramid complex.
A city in the Peruvian Andes, was once capital of the Inca Empire, and is now known for its archaeological remains and Spanish colonial architecture.
India’s capital territory, is a massive metropolitan area in the country’s north.
The capital of Qatar.
The capital city of Ukraine, is a major industrial, scientific, educational and cultural center of Eastern Europe.
The largest city in Nigeria and one of the most populous urban agglomerations.
The capital of Peru, lies on the country's arid Pacific coast.
The capital of Togo.
The capital of Maldives.
The capital of Norway.
The capital of France, known for the Eiffel Tower.
The capital of Western Australia, sits where the Swan River meets the southwest coast.
The capital of Morocco.
The capital of Latvia.
The capital of Italy, home to the Colosseum and the Vatican City.
The capital of Tunisia.
The capital of Liechtenstein.
The capital of Ghana.
The capital of Azerbaijan.
The capital of Belarus.
The capital of Cape Verde.
The capital of Ecuador.

normal.hint: The economic capital of Ivory Coast and one of the most populous French-speaking cities in Africa.
The capital of the United Arab Emirates.
The capital of the Netherlands.
The capital of Turkey, a modern European city with a rich history.
The capital of Madagascar.
The capital of Turkmenistan.
The capital of Kazakhstan.
The capital of Paraguay.
The capital of Greece, the heart of Ancient Greece, a powerful civilization and empire.
The most populous city in New Zealand, located in the North Island.
The capital of Mali.
The capital of Thailand, known for its ornate shrines and vibrant street life.
The capital of Saint Kitts and Nevis.
The capital of China, home to the Forbidden City and the Great Wall.
The capital of Lebanon.
The capital of Serbia.
The capital city of Brazil’s Minas Gerais state.
The capital of Germany, known for the Brandenburg Gate and the Berlin Wall Memorial.
The capital of Kyrgyzstan.
Colombia's sprawling, high-altitude capital.
The capital of Brazil, known for its unique modern architecture.
The capital of Slovakia.
The capital of Queensland, is a large city on the Brisbane River.
The capital of Romania.
Hungary’s capital, is bisected by the River Danube.
The largest city in the Mount Lebanon Governorate of Lebanon. It is believed to have been first occupied between 8800 and 7000 BC and continuously inhabited since 5000 BC.
The capital of Australia, known for its large man-made lake, Lake Burley Griffin.
The capital of Venezuela.
The largest city of Morocco.
The capital of Saint Lucia.
A major city in Illinois, known for its architecture and deep-dish pizza.
The capital of Moldova.
The capital of Senegal.
The capital of Syria, it is also the country's largest city.
The capital city of Bangladesh, is a major center of the country's economy, politics and culture.
The capital of Tanzania.
The capital of Ireland.
The capital city of the fictional Land of Oz in L. Frank Baum's Oz books.
The capital of Sierra Leone.
The capital of Tuvalu.
The capital of Vietnam.
The capital of Zimbabwe.
The only all-wizarding village in Britain. It was founded by medieval wizard Hengist of Woodcroft.
A fictional British boarding school of magic for students aged eleven to eighteen, and is the primary setting for the first six books in J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
The capital of the Solomon Islands.
A large metropolis in Texas, known for its role in the space exploration industry.
The capital of Pakistan.
A major city in Turkey that straddles Europe and Asia across the Bosphorus Strait.
A city in the Middle East, located on a plateau in the Judaean Mountains between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea.
The largest city in South Africa, and is one of the 50 largest urban areas in the world.
The capital of South Sudan.
The capital of Uganda.
The capital of the Pakistani province of Sindh. It is the most populous city in Pakistan, and seventh-most-populous city proper in the world.
The capital of Nepal.
The capital of Sudan.
The capital of Rwanda.
The capital of Jamaica.
The capital of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.
The capital and the largest city of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
The capital of Malawi.
The capital of Portugal.
The capital of Slovenia.
The capital of the United Kingdom, known for the River Thames and the Tower of London.
The capital of Zambia.
The capital of Luxembourg.
A city on the east bank of the Nile River in southern Egypt.
The capital of Spain, home to the Royal Palace and the Prado Museum.
The capital of the Marshall Islands.
The capital of Nicaragua.
The capital of the Philippines, is a densely populated bayside city on the island of Luzon.
The capital of Mozambique.
The capital of Lesotho.
The coastal capital of the southeastern Australian state of Victoria.
A fictional city appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics, best known as the home of Superman.
The capital of Mexico, one of the oldest cities in the Americas.
The capital of Somalia.
The capital of Monaco.
The capital of Liberia.
A major industrial city in northern Mexico.
The capital of Uruguay.
The second-most populous city in Canada, known for its French colonial history and cobblestone streets.
The capital of Russia, known for the Kremlin and Red Square.
Formerly Bombay, a densely populated city on India’s west coast.
The capital of Oman.
The capital and largest city of Kenya.
The capital of Myanmar.
The capital of India, a bustling city with a rich history.
The capital of Palau.
The capital of Niger.

gameData.description: Common items found in a household.

easy.hint: A piece of furniture used for sleep or rest.
A round, deep dish or basin used for food or liquid.
A separate seat for one person, typically with a back and four legs.
A garment worn on the upper body by either sex, for warmth or fashion.
A small bowl-shaped container for drinking from, typically having a handle.

A piece of furniture with a flat table-style work surface used in a school, office, home or the like for academic, professional or domestic activities such as reading, writing, or using equipment such as a computer.
A garment traditionally worn by women or girls consisting of a skirt with an attached bodice (or a matching bodice giving the effect of a one-piece garment).
A device with rotating blades that creates a current of air for cooling or ventilation.
A sticky substance used for joining things together.

A head covering which is worn for various reasons, including protection against weather conditions, ceremonial reasons such as university graduation, religious reasons, safety, or as a fashion accessory.
A type of pants or trousers, typically made from denim or dungaree cloth.
A small piece of shaped metal with incisions cut to fit the wards of a particular lock, which is inserted into a lock and turned to open or close it.
An instrument with a sharp blade and a handle, used for cutting.
A large long-handled spoon with a cup-shaped bowl, used for serving soup, stew, or sauce.
An instrument designed to indicate whether a surface is horizontal (level) or vertical (plumb).
An enclosed compartment, as in a kitchen range, for cooking and heating food.

A thin sheet material produced by mechanically or chemically processing cellulose fibres derived from wood, rags, grasses or other vegetable sources in water, draining the water through fine mesh leaving the fibre evenly distributed on the surface, followed by pressing and drying.
A common writing instrument that applies ink to a surface, usually paper, for writing or drawing.
A piece of footwear intended to protect and comfort the human foot.
The lower part of a dress or gown, covering the person from the waist downwards, or a separate outer garment serving this purpose.
A substance used with water for washing and cleaning, made of a compound of natural oils or fats with sodium hydroxide or another strong alkali, and typically having perfume and coloring added.
A piece of clothing worn on the feet and often covering the ankle or some part of the calf.
A long upholstered seat with a back and arms, for two or more people.
An implement consisting of a small shallow bowl, oval or round, at the end of a handle, used for eating, stirring, and serving food.
An apparatus for cooking or heating that operates by burning fuel or using electricity.
A piece of furniture with a flat top and one or more legs, providing a level surface on which objects may be placed, and that can be used for eating, writing, or working.
An adhesive tape used to stick objects together.
A piece of thick absorbent cloth or paper used for drying oneself or wiping things dry.
A piece of furniture used as a place to sleep or rest.
A flexible band or strap, typically made of leather or heavy cloth and worn around the waist.
A round, deep dish or basin used for food or liquid.
A piece of thick, stiff paper or thin pasteboard, in particular one used for writing or printing on.
A small plastic disc on which digital information is stored.
A separate seat for one person, typically with a back and four legs.
A flat, typically round piece of metal with an official stamp, used as money.
A strip of plastic, metal, or wood with a row of narrow teeth, used for untangling or arranging the hair.
A small bowl-shaped container for drinking from, typically having a handle.
A piece of furniture with a flat table-top and one or more drawers, used as a workplace for reading, writing, or using a computer.
A hinged, sliding, or revolving barrier at the entrance to a building, room, or vehicle, or in the framework of a cupboard.
A tool or machine with a rotating cutting tip or reciprocating hammer or chisel, used for making holes in hard materials.
A percussion instrument sounded by being struck with sticks or the hands, typically cylindrical, barrel-shaped, or bowl-shaped with a taut membrane over one or both ends.
A piece of cloth or similar material, typically oblong or rectangular, attachable by one edge to a pole or rope and used as the symbol or emblem of a country or institution or as a decoration.
A soft thread of silk or cotton, used for embroidery or for cleaning between the teeth.
A wind instrument made from a tube with holes along it that are stopped by the fingers or keys, held vertically or horizontally so that the player's breath strikes a narrow edge.
A utensil, usually having two or more prongs, used for lifting food to the mouth or holding it when cutting.
A device for cooking food by applying heat from below.
Hard-wearing trousers made of denim or other cotton fabric, for informal wear.
A toy consisting of a light frame with thin material stretched over it, flown in the wind at the end of a long string.
An instrument composed of a blade fixed into a handle, used for cutting.
A fine open fabric of cotton or silk, made by looping, twisting, or knitting thread in patterns and used especially for trimming garments.
A metal bar with a catch and lever used for fastening a door or gate.
A line of plastic construction toys that are manufactured by The Lego Group, a privately held company based in Billund, Denmark.

normal.hint: A simple device for binding sheets of paper together. It leaves the paper intact and can be removed quickly and easily, unlike the staple.
A large piece of woolen or similar material used as a covering on a bed or elsewhere for warmth.
A kitchen and laboratory appliance used to mix, purée, or emulsify food and other substances.
A shelf on which books can be stored.
A piece of furniture with doors and shelves or drawers, used for storing or displaying articles.
A device for opening tin cans.
An electric appliance that brews coffee.
A kitchen utensil used to strain foods such as pasta or to rinse vegetables.
A machine for washing dishes automatically.
A piece of furniture with drawers for storing clothes.
A machine or device for drying something, especially the hair or laundry.
A cloth- or scrim-backed pressure-sensitive tape, often coated with polyethylene.
A portable hand-held electric light.
A utensil, usually having two or more prongs, used for lifting food to the mouth or holding it when cutting.
A kitchen utensil used to grate foods into fine pieces.
A tool consisting of a weighted 'head' fixed to a long handle that is swung to deliver an impact to a small area of an object.
A mid-stomach–length garment for the upper body.
A device for giving light, either one consisting of an electric bulb together with its holder and shade or cover, or one burning gas or oil and consisting of a wick or mantle and a glass chimney.
A small table or cabinet designed to stand beside a bed or sofa.
A book or stack of paper pages that are often ruled and used for purposes such as recording notes or memoranda, other writing, drawing or scrapbooking.
A low upholstered seat without a back or arms.
A device used to hold sheets of paper together, usually made of steel wire bent to a looped shape.
A writing utensil with a solid pigment core encased in a protective outer casing.
A rectangular cloth bag stuffed with feathers, foam rubber, or other soft materials, used to support the head when lying down.
A flat dish, typically circular and made of china, from which food is eaten or served.
A hand tool used to hold objects firmly, for bending, or physical compression.

An instrument used for cutting cloth, paper, and other thin material, consisting of two blades laid one on top of the other and fastened in the middle so as to allow them to be opened and closed by a thumb and finger inserted through rings on the end of their handles.
A tool, manual or powered, used for screwing and unscrewing (inserting and removing) screws.
A liquid preparation containing soap or detergent, used for washing the hair.
A self-contained appliance for heating an enclosed area.
A small implement with a broad, flat, blunt blade, used for mixing, spreading, and lifting.
A mechanical device that joins pages of paper or similar material by driving a thin metal staple through the sheets and folding the ends.
A piece of clothing, typically with long sleeves, made of knitted or crocheted material, that covers the upper part of the body.
A style of fabric shirt named after the T shape of its body and sleeves.
An electric appliance that toasts bread slices.
A small brush with a long handle, used for cleaning the teeth.
A paste or gel dentifrice used with a toothbrush to clean and maintain the aesthetics and health of teeth.
A device consisting of a circular canopy of cloth on a folding metal frame supported by a central rod, used as protection against rain or sometimes sun.
An electrical apparatus that by means of suction collects dust and small particles from floors and other surfaces.

A kitchen tool consisting of a slotted metal blade attached to a handle that is used to remove the outer skin or peel of certain vegetables, often potatoes and carrots, and fruits such as apples and pears.
A small, flat case for holding money, credit cards, and other personal items.
A cooking utensil which can be used to blend ingredients smooth and to incorporate air into a mixture, in a process known as whisking or whipping.
A tool used to provide grip and mechanical advantage in applying torque to turn objects—usually rotary fasteners, such as nuts and bolts—or keep them from turning.
A bag carried on one's back, typically with two straps over the shoulders.
A brand of adhesive bandage.
A container that is traditionally constructed from stiff fibers.
A device consisting of one or more electrochemical cells with external connections for powering electrical devices.
A vehicle composed of two wheels held in a frame one behind the other, propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars attached to the front wheel.
An optical instrument with a lens for each eye, used for viewing distant objects.
A large piece of woolen or similar material used as a covering on a bed or for warmth.
A kitchen and laboratory appliance used to mix, emulsify, purée or liquefy food and other substances.
A written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers.
A strip of leather, card, or other material used to mark one's place in a book.
A shelf on which books can be stored.
A container, typically made of glass or plastic and having a narrow neck, used for holding liquids.
A container with a flat base and sides, typically square or rectangular and having a lid.
An ornamental band, hoop, or chain worn on the wrist or arm.
A long-handled brush of bristles or twigs used for sweeping.
A roughly cylindrical open container with a handle, made of metal or plastic and used to hold and carry things.
A small disk or knob sewn on to a garment, either to fasten it by being pushed through a slit made for the purpose or for decoration.
A portable electronic device used to perform calculations, ranging from basic arithmetic to complex mathematics.
A chart or series of pages showing the days, weeks, and months of a particular year, or giving particular seasonal information.
A device for recording visual images in the form of photographs, film, or video signals.
A device for opening tin cans.
A cylinder or block of wax or tallow with a central wick that is lit to produce light as it burns.
A length of cane or a slender stick, especially one used as a support for plants, as a walking stick, or as an instrument of punishment.
A road vehicle, typically with four wheels, powered by an internal combustion engine or electric motor and able to carry a small number of people.
A floor covering made from thick woven fabric.
An indoor feces and urine collection box for cats.
A white, soft, earthy limestone formed from the skeletal remains of sea creatures.
A board with a dark smooth surface, used for writing on with chalk.
A device for charging a battery or battery-powered equipment.
A pair of small, thin sticks of equal length, held together in one hand and used as eating utensils in some Asian countries.
A thin cylinder of finely cut tobacco rolled in paper for smoking.
A small board with a spring clip at the top, used for holding papers and providing support for writing.
A mechanical or electrical device for measuring time, indicating hours, minutes, and sometimes seconds, typically by hands on a round dial or by displayed figures.
A cup from which coffee is drunk.
An electronic device for storing and processing data, typically in binary form, according to instructions given to it in a variable program.
A jar for storing cookies.
A tool for drawing corks from bottles, consisting of a pointed metallic helix attached to a handle.
A long upholstered seat with a back and arms, for two or more people.
A pencil or stick of colored chalk or wax, used for drawing.
A payment card issued to users to enable the cardholder to pay a merchant for goods and services.
A piece of material suspended at the top to form a screen, typically movable sideways along a rail and found as one of a pair at a window.
A bag of cloth stuffed with a mass of soft material, used as a comfortable support for sitting or leaning on.
A chemical substance, usually in the form of a powder or liquid, that is used for washing things such as clothes or dishes.
A piece of absorbent material wrapped around a baby's bottom and between its legs to absorb and retain urine and feces.
A book or electronic resource that lists the words of a language and gives their meaning, or gives the equivalent words in a different language.
A shallow, flat-bottomed container for cooking or serving food.
A machine for cleaning dishware and cutlery automatically.
A handle on a door that is turned to release the latch.
A box-like storage compartment without a lid, made to slide horizontally in and out of a desk, chest, or other piece of furniture.
A one-piece garment for a woman or girl that covers the body and extends down over the legs.
A short bar with a weight at each end, used in pairs for exercise or muscle-building.
A pan into which dust and refuse are swept from the floor.
A type of compact disc able to store large amounts of data, especially high-resolution audiovisual material.
A piece of jewelry worn on the lobe or edge of the ear.
A small hourglass or other timer for indicating the time required to boil an egg.
A razor with a rotating or oscillating blade.
A flat paper container with a sealable flap, used to enclose a letter or document.
A piece of soft rubber or plastic used to rub out something written.
An insulated flexible electric wire fitted with a plug at one end and one or more sockets at the other.
A pair of lenses set in a frame resting on the nose and ears, used in correcting or assisting defective eyesight or protecting the eyes.
A machine with rotating blades that creates a current of air for cooling or ventilation.
A device by which a flow of liquid or gas from a pipe or container can be controlled; a tap.
A portable device that discharges a jet of water, foam, gas, or other material to extinguish a fire.
A structure of brick, stone, or metal designed to contain a fire.
A portable hand-held electric light.
A container in which to grow flowers.
A folding cover or holder, typically made of stiff paper or cardboard, for storing loose papers.
A shallow pan with a long handle, used for frying food.
A tube or pipe that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for guiding liquid or powder into a small opening.
A type of paper designed for gift wrapping.
Frames bearing lenses worn in front of the eyes.
A garment covering the whole hand.
A sticky substance used for joining things together.
A kitchen utensil used to grate foods into fine pieces.
A string instrument played by plucking or strumming.
A brush for tidying and styling hair.
A tool with a heavy head and a handle, used for tasks such as breaking things and driving in nails.
A small bag used by a woman to carry everyday personal items.
A shaped piece of wood, plastic, or metal with a hook at the top, from which clothes may be hung in order to keep them in shape.
A shaped covering for the head worn for warmth, as a fashion item, or as part of a uniform.
A pair of small loudspeaker drivers worn on or around the head over a user's ears.
A hard or padded protective hat, various types of which are worn by soldiers, police officers, firefighters, motorcyclists, athletes, and others.
A felt-tip pen with a broad nib and transparent fluorescent ink, used to mark passages of text.
A device for making holes in sheets of paper.
A plant grown indoors in places such as residences and offices.
A pen that uses ink to write.
An outer garment extending either to the waist or the hips, typically having sleeves and a fastening down the front.
A cylindrical container, typically made of glass, with a wide mouth.
A rope used in the sport of skipping.
A small piece of shaped metal with incisions cut to fit the wards of a particular lock, which is inserted into a lock and turned to open or close it.
A peripheral device which models a typewriter keyboard.
A bag with shoulder straps, carried on the back, and typically made of canvas or other weatherproof material.
A protective pad for the knee.
A large long-handled spoon with a cup-shaped bowl, used for serving soup, stew, or sauce.
A device for giving light, either one consisting of an electric bulb together with its holder and shade, or one using oil or gas as fuel.
A cover for a lamp, used to soften the light.

A small, portable personal computer with a 'clamshell' form factor, typically having a thin LCD or LED computer screen mounted on the inside of the upper lid of the 'clamshell' and an alphanumeric keyboard on the inside of the lower lid.
A machine for cutting the grass on a lawn.

difficult.hint: A system for cooling and dehumidifying the air in a building.
A device for opening metal bottle caps.
A durable board on which to place material for cutting.
A cup marked in graded amounts, used for measuring ingredients in cooking.
A spoon used to measure an amount of an ingredient, either liquid or dry, when cooking.
An appliance or compartment which is artificially kept cool and used to store food and drink.
A loop of rubber, in any of various sizes, used to hold things together.
A flexible ruler used to measure size or distance.
A knife with a small sharp blade, often retractable, designed to cut wood, cardboard, and other materials.
A machine used to wash laundry, such as clothing and sheets.
A pen that dispenses ink over a metal ball at its point.
A device for opening screw-top bottles.
A long knife with a serrated blade, for slicing bread.
A device for holding a candle.
A sealed plastic unit containing a length of audiotape or videotape wound on a pair of spools, for insertion into a recorder or playback machine.

A device in the shape of human shoulders designed to facilitate the hanging of a coat, jacket, sweater, shirt, blouse or dress in a manner that prevents wrinkles, with a lower bar for the hanging of trousers or skirts.
A machine that brews coffee.
A piece of office furniture with deep drawers for storing documents.
A container for temporary storage of waste.
A flexible tube used to convey water.
A square of cotton or other finely woven material, intended for wiping one's nose.
A tray for making ice cubes.
A long, narrow board, often with folding legs, on which clothes, sheets, etc. are ironed.
A box for storing jewelry.
Any of several knives used in the preparation of food.
A jacket-length coat that is usually worn on top of other apparel or item of clothing, and made from the tanned hide of various animals.

gameData.description: Historical and modern figures who have made a significant impact on the world.

easy.hint: An American singer, actress and television personality.
The presumed author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems that are the central works of ancient Greek literature.
The prophet and the founder of Manichaeism, a gnostic religion of late antiquity which was once widespread but is now extinct.
A prophet in Abrahamic religions.
An Athenian philosopher during the Classical period in Ancient Greece, founder of the Platonist school of thought, and the Academy, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world.
A British rock band formed in London in 1970. Their classic line-up was Freddie Mercury (lead vocals, piano), Brian May (guitar, vocals), Roger Taylor (drums, vocals), and John Deacon (bass).

normal.hint: An English mathematician, computer scientist, logician, cryptanalyst, philosopher, and theoretical biologist.
He developed the theory of relativity.
A king of the ancient Greek kingdom of Macedon and a member of the Argead dynasty.
A Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, inventor, and astronomer.
A Greek philosopher and polymath during the Classical period in Ancient Greece.
The first Roman emperor, reigning from 27 BC until his death in AD 14.
An American singer, songwriter, actress, and record producer.
An American business magnate, software developer, investor, and philanthropist. He is a co-founder of Microsoft Corporation.
An American singer-songwriter, author and visual artist. Widely regarded as one of the greatest songwriters of all time, Dylan has been a major figure in popular culture for more than 50 years.
A philosopher, mendicant, meditator, spiritual teacher, and religious leader who lived in ancient India.
A Chinese eunuch court official of the Han dynasty, traditionally regarded as the inventor of paper.
A Canadian singer.
A British-American film director, producer, and screenwriter. His films have grossed over $5 billion worldwide, and have garnered 11 Academy Awards from 36 nominations.

A French painter, a founder of French Impressionist painting and the most consistent and prolific practitioner of the movement's philosophy of expressing one's perceptions before nature, especially as applied to plein air landscape painting.
She was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.
A Chinese philosopher and politician of the Spring and Autumn period who was traditionally considered the paragon of Chinese sages.
A Scottish Enlightenment philosopher, historian, economist, and essayist, who is best known today for his highly influential system of philosophical empiricism, skepticism, and naturalism.
The founder, CEO, and chief engineer at SpaceX; early stage investor, CEO, and product architect of Tesla, Inc.
An Italian and naturalized-American physicist and the creator of the world's first nuclear reactor, the Chicago Pile-1.
An American novelist, short-story writer, journalist, and sportsman.
A Greek mathematician, often referred to as the 'founder of geometry' or the 'father of geometry'.
A Portuguese explorer who organised the Spanish expedition to the East Indies from 1519 to 1522, resulting in the first circumnavigation of the Earth, which was completed by Juan Sebastián Elcano.
A Spanish conquistador who led the Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire.
The founder and first Great Khan of the Mongol Empire, which became the largest contiguous empire in history after his death.
An English poet and author. Widely considered the greatest English poet of the Middle Ages, he is best known for The Canterbury Tales.
An American artist. She was known for her paintings of enlarged flowers, New York skyscrapers, and New Mexico landscapes.
A meteorologist, mathematician, biologist, Augustinian friar and abbot of St. Thomas' Abbey in Brno, Margraviate of Moravia.
An American biologist and researcher who co-invented the combined oral contraceptive pill.
An American actor, pilot, and environmental activist.
The fifth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt.
An American industrialist and business magnate, founder of the Ford Motor Company, and chief developer of the assembly line technique of mass production.
A Scottish inventor, mechanical engineer, and chemist whose Watt steam engine, an improvement of the Newcomen steam engine, was fundamental to the changes brought by the Industrial Revolution.
An English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century.
A French painter whose brief career spurred the revival of interest in colour and movement, as seen in the tradition of Correggio and Rubens.

A Genevan philosopher, writer, and composer. His political philosophy influenced the progress of the Enlightenment throughout Europe, as well as aspects of the French Revolution and the development of modern political, economic, and educational thought.
An American entrepreneur, media proprietor, investor, and computer engineer. He is the founder and executive chairman of Amazon.
A French theologian, pastor and reformer in Geneva during the Protestant Reformation.
An English philosopher and physician, widely regarded as one of the most influential of Enlightenment thinkers and commonly known as the 'Father of Liberalism'.
An English economist, whose ideas fundamentally changed the theory and practice of macroeconomics and the economic policies of governments.
A British surgeon and a pioneer of antiseptic surgery.
An ancient Chinese philosopher and writer. He is the reputed author of the Tao Te Ching, the founder of philosophical Taoism, and a deity in religious Taoism and traditional Chinese religions.
A French artist and photographer, recognized for his invention of the daguerreotype process of photography.
An American singer, songwriter, and actress. She is known for her continual reinvention and versatility in music production, songwriting, and visual presentation.

A Chinese communist revolutionary who was the founder of the People's Republic of China, which he ruled as the chairman of the Communist Party of China from its establishment in 1949 until his death in 1976.
A Venetian merchant, explorer, and writer who travelled through Asia along the Silk Road between 1271 and 1295.
A pioneer in radioactivity research, she was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
An American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer.
An American media magnate, internet entrepreneur, and philanthropist. He is known for co-founding Facebook, Inc. and serves as its chairman, chief executive officer, and controlling shareholder.
An American Baptist minister and activist who became the most visible spokesperson and leader in the civil rights movement.
A German theoretical physicist whose discovery of energy quanta won him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1918.
A pharaoh of the Early Dynastic Period of ancient Egypt credited by classical tradition with having united Upper and Lower Egypt and as the founder of the First Dynasty.
An Italian sculptor, painter, architect and poet of the High Renaissance born in the Republic of Florence, who exerted an unparalleled influence on the development of Western art.
The founder of Islam, believed by Muslims to be a prophet of God.
A German engineer who successfully developed the compressed charge internal combustion engine which ran on petroleum gas and led to the modern internal combustion engine.
A Danish physicist who made foundational contributions to understanding atomic structure and quantum theory, for which he received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1922.
Two American aviation pioneers generally credited with inventing, building, and flying the world's first successful motor-operated airplane.
An ancient Ionian Greek philosopher and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism.
Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 20 June 1837 until her death in 1901.
A Dutch draughtsman, painter, and printmaker.
An American poet. His work was initially published in England before it was published in the United States.
An American activist in the civil rights movement best known for her pivotal role in the Montgomery bus boycott.
An American professional tennis player. She has won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, the most by any player in the Open Era.
A Greek philosopher from Athens who is credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy, and as being the first moral philosopher of the Western ethical tradition of thought.
A Christian theologian and philosopher, whose writings influenced the development of Western Christianity and Western philosophy.
An apostle who taught the gospel of Christ to the first-century world.
He was the co-founder, chairman, and CEO of Apple Inc.

An American film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is considered one of the founding pioneers of the New Hollywood era, as well as one of the most popular directors and producers in film history.
A Chinese statesman, physician, and political philosopher, who served as the provisional first president of the Republic of China and the first leader of the Kuomintang.
An English rock band, formed in Liverpool in 1960, that comprised John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr.
An English rock band formed in London in 1962.
An American statesman, diplomat, lawyer, architect, philosopher, and Founding Father who served as the third president of the United States from 1801 to 1809.
An American actor and filmmaker.
A Dutch Baroque Period painter who specialized in domestic interior scenes of middle-class life.
An ancient Roman poet of the Augustan period. He wrote three of the most famous poems in Latin literature: the Eclogues (or Bucolics), the Georgics, and the epic Aeneid.
An American business magnate, investor, and philanthropist. He is currently the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway.
An English playwright, poet, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.
The first Norman King of England, reigning from 1066 until his death in 1087.
An ancient Iranian-speaking prophet whose teachings and innovations on the religious traditions of ancient Iranian-speaking peoples developed into the religion of Zoroastrianism.

difficult.hint: An American lawyer and statesman who served as the 16th president of the United States from 1861 until his assassination in 1865.
A Japanese film director and screenwriter who directed 30 films in a career spanning 57 years.
A Scottish physician and microbiologist, best known for his discovery of the antibiotic substance penicillin in 1928.
A Scottish-born inventor, scientist, and engineer who is credited with patenting the first practical telephone.
An English film director, producer, and screenwriter. He is one of the most influential and extensively studied filmmakers in the history of cinema.
An American aviation pioneer and author. She was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
A Scottish-American industrialist and philanthropist.
An American artist, film director, and producer who was a leading figure in the visual art movement known as pop art.
A French nobleman and chemist who was a central figure in the 18th-century chemical revolution and who had a large influence on both the history of chemistry and the history of biology.
A Dutch businessman and scientist in the Golden Age of Dutch science and technology.
An American vocal group, formed in Orlando, Florida in 1993.

One of the Founding Fathers of the United States, he was also a leading author, printer, political theorist, politician, freemason, postmaster, scientist, inventor, humorist, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat.
A French mathematician, physicist, inventor, writer and Catholic theologian.
An English polymath.
An English naturalist, geologist and biologist, best known for his contributions to the science of evolution.
An English writer and social critic. He created some of the world's best-known fictional characters and is regarded by many as the greatest novelist of the Victorian era.
An Italian explorer and navigator who completed four voyages across the Atlantic Ocean, opening the way for European exploration and colonization of the Americas.
A pioneering American nurse who founded the American Red Cross.
A Roman emperor who ruled between 306 and 337 AD.
A Portuguese professional footballer who plays as a forward for Premier League club Manchester United and captains the Portugal national team.
The founder of the Achaemenid Empire, the first Persian Empire.

An Italian poet, writer and philosopher. His Divine Comedy, originally called Comedìa and later christened Divina by Giovanni Boccaccio, is widely considered one of the most important poems of the Middle Ages and the greatest literary work in the Italian language.
A South African Anglican cleric and theologian known for his work as an anti-apartheid and human rights activist.
An American actor, producer, businessman, and former professional wrestler.
An American writer, poet, editor, and literary critic. Poe is best known for his poetry and short stories, particularly his tales of mystery and the macabre.

An American political figure, diplomat and activist. She served as the First Lady of the United States from March 4, 1933, to April 12, 1945, during her husband President Franklin D. Roosevelt's four terms in office, making her the longest-serving First Lady of the United States.
An American singer and actor. Dubbed the 'King of Rock and Roll', he is regarded as one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century.
An American poet. Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts, into a prominent family with strong ties to its community.
A New Zealand physicist who came to be known as the father of nuclear physics.
A French Romantic artist regarded from the outset of his career as the leader of the French Romantic school.
An English social reformer, statistician and the founder of modern nursing.
A British molecular biologist, biophysicist, and neuroscientist.
An American politician who served as the 32nd president of the United States from 1933 until his death in 1945.
A Mexican painter known for her many portraits, self-portraits, and works inspired by the nature and artifacts of Mexico.
A German philosopher, cultural critic, composer, poet, and philologist whose work has exerted a profound influence on modern intellectual history.
An Italian astronomer, physicist and engineer, whose observations of the cosmos were revolutionary.

An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and entrepreneur. He is best known for creating the Star Wars and Indiana Jones franchises and founding Lucasfilm, LucasArts, and Industrial Light & Magic.
An English novelist, essayist, journalist and critic. His work is characterised by lucid prose, biting social criticism, opposition to totalitarianism, and outspoken support of democratic socialism.
An American political leader, military general, statesman, and Founding Father who served as the first president of the United States from 1789 to 1797.
A French post-Impressionist artist. He is best known for devising the painting techniques known as chromoluminarism and pointillism.
An Italian inventor and electrical engineer, known for his pioneering work on long-distance radio transmission and for his development of Marconi's law and a radio telegraph system.

An American abolitionist and political activist. Born into slavery, Tubman escaped and subsequently made some thirteen missions to rescue approximately seventy enslaved people, family and friends, using the network of antislavery activists and safe houses known as the Underground Railroad.
A Spanish Conquistador who led an expedition that caused the fall of the Aztec Empire.
A German philosopher and one of the central Enlightenment thinkers.
An English mathematician, physicist, astronomer, theologian, and author who is widely recognised as one of the most influential scientists of all time.
A Russian physiologist known primarily for his work in classical conditioning.

A British author, philanthropist, film producer, television producer, and screenwriter. She is best known for writing the Harry Potter fantasy series, which has won multiple awards and sold more than 500 million copies, becoming the best-selling book series in history.
A French naval officer, explorer, conservationist, filmmaker, innovator, scientist, photographer, author and researcher who studied the sea and all forms of life in water.

A Canadian film director, producer, screenwriter, editor, and environmentalist. He is a major figure in the post-New Hollywood era and is considered one of the most innovative filmmakers in the industry.
A Scottish scientist in the field of mathematical physics.
An American molecular biologist, geneticist and zoologist.
A French philosopher, playwright, novelist, political activist, biographer, and literary critic.
An American comedian, actor, writer, and producer.

An American musician, singer, and songwriter. Although his mainstream career spanned only four years, he is widely regarded as one of the most influential electric guitarists in the history of popular music, and one of a kind.
A German composer and musician of the Baroque period.
A German blacksmith, goldsmith, printer, and publisher who introduced printing to Europe with his mechanical movable-type printing press.
An American business magnate and philanthropist. He is widely considered the wealthiest American of all time, and the richest person in modern history.
An English chemist, physicist, and meteorologist.
An American politician who served as the 35th president of the United States from 1961 until his assassination in 1963.

A Georgian revolutionary and Soviet politician who led the Soviet Union from the mid–1920s until 1953 as General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (1922–1952) and Premier (1941–1953).
An American actress and producer.
A Roman general and statesman who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire.
The Eastern Roman emperor from 527 to 565.
An American actor, film producer, and environmentalist.
An Italian mathematician from the Republic of Pisa, considered to be 'the most talented Western mathematician of the Middle Ages'.
He painted the Mona Lisa.
An Argentine professional footballer who plays as a forward for Ligue 1 club Paris Saint-Germain and captains the Argentina national team.
A French biologist, microbiologist and chemist renowned for his discoveries of the principles of vaccination, microbial fermentation and pasteurization.
A German composer and pianist. A crucial figure in the transition between the Classical and Romantic eras in Western art music, he remains one of the most recognized and influential of all composers.
An Indian lawyer, anti-colonial nationalist, and political ethicist, who employed nonviolent resistance to lead the successful campaign for India's independence from British Rule.
A Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest Nobel Prize laureate.

An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and actor. One of the major figures of the New Hollywood era, he is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential directors in film history.
A German physicist who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1914 for his discovery of the diffraction of X-rays by crystals.
An American poet, singer, memoirist, and civil rights activist.
An English scientist who contributed to the study of electromagnetism and electrochemistry.
An American singer, songwriter, and dancer. Dubbed the 'King of Pop', he is regarded as one of the most significant cultural figures of the 20th century.
An American former professional basketball player and businessman.
A Russian and former Soviet politician.
A French military and political leader who rose to prominence during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars.
An American astronaut and aeronautical engineer, and the first person to walk on the Moon.
He was a South African anti-apartheid revolutionary and political leader.
A Renaissance-era mathematician and astronomer who formulated a model of the universe that placed the Sun rather than Earth at the center of the universe.
A Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, and futurist who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electrical system.
An English military and political leader.
An American talk show host, television producer, actress, author, and philanthropist.
A Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist and theatre designer who spent most of his adult life in France.
A monarch of the Tsardom of Russia and later the Russian Empire from 7 May 1682 until his death in 1725.
The head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 12 March 1088 to his death.
The founder of the Qin dynasty and was the first emperor of a unified China.
Queen of England and Ireland from 17 November 1558 until her death in 1603.
Queen of Castile from 1474 until her death.

An American film director, screenwriter, producer, and actor. His films are characterized by nonlinear storylines, satirical subject matter, an aestheticization of violence, extended scenes of dialogue, ensemble casts, references to popular culture, and a wide variety of music.
A French-born philosopher, mathematician, and scientist who spent a large portion of his working life in the Dutch Republic.
An English business magnate, investor, and author. In the 1970s he founded the Virgin Group, which today controls more than 400 companies in various fields.
A Norwegian explorer of polar regions. He was a key figure of the period known as the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration.
An American actor and comedian.
A Spanish surrealist artist renowned for his technical skill, precise draftsmanship, and the striking and bizarre images in his work.
An Austrian neurologist and the founder of psychoanalysis, a clinical method for treating psychopathology through dialogue between a patient and a psychoanalyst.
A Venezuelan military and political leader who led what are currently the countries of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama to independence from the Spanish Empire.
A New Zealand mountaineer, explorer, and philanthropist. On 29 May 1953, he and Sherpa mountaineer Tenzing Norgay became the first climbers confirmed to have reached the summit of Mount Everest.
A British pop girl group formed in 1994.
An American film director, producer, screenwriter, and photographer. He is frequently cited as one of the most influential filmmakers in cinematic history.
An English theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author who was director of research at the Centre for Theoretical Cosmology at the University of Cambridge at the time of his death.
An American social reformer and women's rights activist who played a pivotal role in the women's suffrage movement.
An American singer-songwriter. Her narrative songwriting, which often centers around her personal life, has received widespread critical praise and media coverage.
The spiritual leader of the Tibetan people.
An American inventor and businessman who has been described as America's greatest inventor.
An English cleric, scholar and influential economist in the fields of political economy and demography.
An American professional golfer.
The second Rashidun Caliph, ruling from August 634 until his assassination in 644.
A Portuguese explorer and the first European to reach India by sea.
A Dutch Post-Impressionist painter who is among the most famous and influential figures in the history of Western art.
An English writer, considered one of the most important modernist 20th-century authors and also a pioneer in the use of stream of consciousness as a narrative device.
A Russian revolutionary, politician, and political theorist.
An American entrepreneur, animator, writer, voice actor, and film producer.
A German theoretical physicist and one of the key pioneers of quantum mechanics.
An English physician who made influential contributions in anatomy and physiology.
A British statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1940 to 1945, during the Second World War, and again from 1951 to 1955.
A prolific and influential composer of the Classical period.

gameData.description: Dishes, ingredients, and cuisines from around the world.

easy.hint: To cook uncovered by dry heat, usually in an oven or oven-like appliance.
A culinary herb of the family Lamiaceae (mints).
To moisten foods with pan drippings or sauces during cooking to add flavor and prevent drying.
A staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually by baking.
A form of sweet food made from flour, sugar, and other ingredients, that is usually baked.
To cut food into small cubes.

A common food and a versatile ingredient in cooking.

A powder made by grinding raw grains, roots, beans, nuts, or seeds.
A green, leafy, cruciferous vegetable that is rich in nutrients.

A staple food of traditional Italian cuisine, with the first reference dating to 1154 in Sicily.
A sweet, mild fruit, the flesh of which is eaten.

gameData.description: Significant events and periods in world history.

easy.hint: The Normandy landings were the landing operations on Tuesday, 6 June 1944 of the Allied invasion of Normandy in Operation Overlord during World War II.
An intergovernmental military alliance between 29 North American and European countries.

normal.hint: A civil war in the United States from 1861 to 1865, fought between the northern states loyal to the Union and the southern states that had seceded to form the Confederate States of America.
A period of cultural history between the 8th century BC and the 6th century AD centered on the Mediterranean Sea.
The final epoch of the three-age division of the prehistory and protohistory of humanity.

A Mesoamerican civilization developed by the Maya peoples, and noted for its logosyllabic script—the most sophisticated and highly developed writing system in pre-Columbian Americas—as well as for its art, architecture, mathematics, calendar, and astronomical system.
The period of European history from the fall of the Roman Empire in the West (5th century) to the fall of Constantinople (1453), or more narrowly, from c. 1100 to 1453.
The 11th-century invasion and occupation of England by an army of Norman, Breton, Flemish, and French soldiers led by the Duke of Normandy, later styled William the Conqueror.
A 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), to achieve superior spaceflight capability.

normal.word: The construction of the Great Wall of China
normal.hint: A series of fortifications that were built across the historical northern borders of ancient Chinese states and Imperial China as protection against various nomadic groups from the Eurasian Steppe.
The arrival of Europeans in the Americas in 1492, led by Christopher Columbus.
The discovery of the structure of DNA by James Watson and Francis Crick in 1953.

normal.word: The signing of the Magna Carta
normal.hint: A royal charter of rights agreed to by King John of England at Runnymede, near Windsor, on 15 June 1215.

A theory developed by Charles Darwin, which states that all species of organisms arise and develop through the natural selection of small, inherited variations that increase the individual's ability to compete, survive, and reproduce.
The period of human activity between the use of the first stone tools and the invention of writing systems.
The period of history that succeeds the Middle Ages.
A period in European history, from the 14th to the 17th century, regarded as the cultural bridge between the Middle Ages and modern history.
A major movement within Western Christianity in 16th-century Europe that posed a religious and political challenge to the Roman Catholic Church and papal authority in particular.
An intellectual and philosophical movement that dominated the world of ideas in Europe during the 18th century.
