The period of Queen Victoria's reign, from 20 June 1837 until her death on 22 January 1901.
A period of rapid economic growth in the United States, from the 1870s to 1900.
A period of geopolitical tension between the Soviet Union with its satellite states, and the United States with its allies after World War II.
The period encompassing the activities related to the Space Race, space exploration, space technology, and the cultural developments influenced by these events.
The post-Roman Republic period of the ancient Roman civilization.

An empire that extended across Eurasia and North America from 1721, following the end of the Great Northern War, until the Republic was proclaimed by the Provisional Government that took power after the February Revolution of 1917.
A series of imperial dynasties centered in Persia.
The period in European history, especially Northern European and Scandinavian history, following the Germanic Iron Age.
The period between the end of the First World War and the beginning of the Second World War.
A broad prehistoric period during which stone was widely used to make tools with an edge, a point, or a percussion surface.
A prehistoric period, approximately 3300 BCE to 1200 BCE, that was characterized by the use of bronze, in some areas proto-writing, and other early features of urban civilization.
The final epoch of the three-age division of the prehistory and protohistory of humanity.
A series of religious wars sanctioned by the Latin Church in the medieval period.
A 17th-century religious conflict fought primarily in Central Europe.
A battle fought on Sunday, 18 June 1815, near Waterloo in present-day Belgium, then part of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands.
A war between North Korea and South Korea.
A war waged by coalition forces from 35 nations led by the United States against Iraq in response to Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait.
A protracted armed conflict that began in 2003 with the invasion of Iraq by a United States-led coalition that overthrew the government of Saddam Hussein.
An unusually deadly influenza pandemic that infected 500 million people across the world, or about 27% of the then world population of between 1.8 and 1.9 billion people.
An invasion of Egypt in late 1956 by Israel, followed by the United Kingdom and France.
A global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918.
A global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945.
A period of geopolitical tension between the Soviet Union with its satellite states, and the United States with its allies after World War II.
A 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union and the United States, for supremacy in spaceflight capability.
A system of institutionalised racial segregation that existed in South Africa and South West Africa from 1948 until the early 1990s.
The right of women to vote in elections.
A political and economic union of 28 member states that are located primarily in Europe.

An intergovernmental organization tasked with maintaining international peace and security, developing friendly relations among nations, achieving international co-operation, and being a centre for harmonizing the actions of nations.
A diplomatic standoff between Iran and the United States.

A major political scandal that occurred in the United States during the early 1970s, following a break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate office complex in Washington, D.C. in 1972 and President Richard Nixon's administration's subsequent attempt to cover up its involvement.
A political scandal in the United States that occurred during the second term of the Reagan Administration.
A policy of more open consultative government and wider dissemination of information, initiated by leader Mikhail Gorbachev from 1985.

The process of internal disintegration within the Soviet Union, which began with growing unrest in its various constituent republics developing into an incessant political and legislative conflict between the republics and the central government, and ended when the leaders of three of the Union's founding republics declared it dissolved in December 1991.
A historic speculative bubble in stocks of Internet-based companies from 1995 to 2001.
The withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union.
A period of history from the 8th to the 3rd century BCE during which, according to German philosopher Karl Jaspers, similar revolutionary thinking appeared in China, India, and the Occident.
The shift from mechanical and analogue electronic technology to digital electronics which began in the latter half of the 20th century.
The period of Soviet history when Joseph Stalin was the leader of the Soviet Union, from 1927 to 1953.
The last division of classical Japanese history, running from 794 to 1185.
The period between 1603 and 1868 in the history of Japan, when Japanese society was under the rule of the Tokugawa shogunate and the country's 300 regional daimyō.
The tripartite division of China among the states of Wei, Shu, and Wu.
A historical periodization traditionally referring to the Middle Ages.

The dominant social system in medieval Europe, in which the nobility held lands from the Crown in exchange for military service, and vassals were in turn tenants of the nobles, while the peasants were obliged to live on their lord's land and give him homage, labor, and a share of the produce, notionally in exchange for military protection.

An essential element of feudal society, was the organizing principle of rural economy that originated in the villa system of the Late Roman Empire, was widely practiced in medieval western and parts of central Europe, and was slowly replaced by the advent of a money-based market economy and new forms of agrarian contract.
An economic system based on the private ownership of the means of production and their operation for profit.

A political, social and economic philosophy encompassing a range of economic and social systems characterised by social ownership of the means of production and workers' self-management of enterprises.

A philosophical, social, political, and economic ideology and movement whose ultimate goal is the establishment of a communist society, namely a socioeconomic order structured upon the ideas of common ownership of the means of production and the absence of social classes, money, and the state.

A network of trade routes which connected the East and West, and was central to the economic, cultural, political, and religious interactions between these regions from the 2nd century BCE to the 18th century.
The transportation by slave traders of various enslaved African people, mainly to the Americas.
The study of the history of the African diaspora.
The study of the role that women have played in history and the methods required to do so.

A humanities discipline within the scope of general historical recording of armed conflict in the history of humanity, and its impact on the societies, cultures and economies thereof, as well as the changes in relations between them.
A field of history that combines the approaches of anthropology and history to look at popular cultural traditions and cultural interpretations of historical experience.

difficult.hint: A civilization belonging to a period of Greek history that lasted from the Archaic period of the 8th to 6th centuries BC to the end of antiquity (c. 600 AD).
A civilization that grew out of a small agricultural community founded on the Italian Peninsula in the 10th century BC.
The period of technological improvement and increased crop productivity that occurred during the 18th and early 19th centuries in Europe.
An ideological and political revolution which occurred in colonial North America between 1765 and 1783.
A Mesoamerican culture that flourished in central Mexico in the post-classic period from 1300 to 1521.
The leading cosmological model for the observable universe from the earliest known periods through its subsequent large-scale evolution.
A bubonic plague pandemic occurring in Afro-Eurasia from 1346 to 1353. It is the most fatal pandemic recorded in human history, causing the death of 75–200 million people in Eurasia and North Africa.
Comprised the dominions, colonies, protectorates, mandates, and other territories ruled or administered by the United Kingdom and its predecessor states.
A historic period, approximately 3300 BCE to 1200 BCE, that was characterized by the use of bronze, in some areas writing, and other early features of urban civilization.
The continuation of the Roman Empire in its eastern provinces during Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages, when its capital city was Constantinople.
A period of geopolitical tension between the United States and the Soviet Union and their respective allies, the Western Bloc and the Eastern Bloc, which began following World War II.
A series of religious wars initiated, supported, and sometimes directed by the Latin Church in the medieval period.

The shift from mechanical and analogue electronic technology to digital electronics which began in the latter half of the 20th century, with the adoption and proliferation of digital computers and digital record keeping, that continues to the present day.
A period of far-reaching social and political upheaval in France and its colonies beginning in 1789 and ending in 1799.
A severe worldwide economic depression that took place mostly during the 1930s, beginning in the United States.
A war waged by coalition forces from 35 nations led by the United States against Iraq in response to Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait.

A series of conflicts in Western Europe from 1337 to 1453, waged between the House of Plantagenet and its cadet House of Lancaster, rulers of the Kingdom of England, and the House of Valois over the right to rule the Kingdom of France.
The largest empire in pre-Columbian America.
The transition to new manufacturing processes in Europe and the United States, in the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840.
A war between North Korea (with the support of China and the Soviet Union) and South Korea (with the support of the United Nations, principally the United States).
The largest contiguous land empire in history, which existed during the 13th and 14th centuries.
A series of major conflicts pitting the French Empire and its allies, led by Napoleon I, against a fluctuating array of European powers formed into various coalitions.
A state that controlled much of Southeastern Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa between the 14th and early 20th centuries.
A series of imperial dynasties centered in Persia (modern-day Iran).
A period in European history, from the 14th to the 17th century, regarded as the cultural bridge between the Middle Ages and modern history.

A decade of economic growth and widespread prosperity driven by recovery from wartime devastation and deferred spending, a boom in construction, and the rapid growth of consumer goods such as automobiles and electricity in North America and Europe and a few other developed countries such as Australia.
A broad prehistoric period during which stone was widely used to make tools with an edge, a point, or a percussion surface.
A conflict in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia from 1 November 1955 to the fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975.
The period from the late 8th century to the mid-11th century in European history, especially Northern European and Scandinavian history, following the Germanic Iron Age.

A series of English civil wars for control of the throne of England fought between supporters of two rival cadet branches of the royal House of Plantagenet: the House of Lancaster, represented by a red rose, and the House of York, represented by a white rose.

difficult.word: The building of the pyramids in Egypt
difficult.hint: The construction of massive stone structures in ancient Egypt, which were built as tombs for the country's pharaohs and their consorts during the Old and Middle Kingdom periods.
The discovery of the principles of electricity, which has led to the development of many technologies that have transformed modern life.
The discovery of the first antibiotic, penicillin, by Alexander Fleming in 1928.

difficult.word: The fall of the Berlin Wall
difficult.hint: A pivotal event in world history which began the process of German reunification and the end of the Cold War.
The invention of a powered, fixed-wing aircraft that is propelled forward by thrust from a jet engine, propeller or rocket engine.

difficult.word: The invention of the light bulb
difficult.hint: The invention of an electric light with a wire filament heated until it glows.

difficult.word: The invention of the printing press
difficult.hint: An invention that allowed for the mass production of books and the rapid dissemination of knowledge throughout Europe.
The invention of a telecommunications device that permits two or more users to conduct a conversation when they are too far apart to be heard directly.

A theory developed by Albert Einstein, which states that the laws of physics are the same for all non-accelerating observers, and that the speed of light in a vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion or the motion of the light source.
A global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918.
A global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945.
The aggregate of past events from the beginning of recorded human history and extending as far as the Early Middle Ages or the Postclassical Era.
The period of cultural history between the 8th century BC and the 6th century AD centered on the Mediterranean Sea.
The period in European history from the collapse of Roman civilization in the 5th century CE to the period of the Renaissance.
The period of modern history between the Late Middle Ages and the beginning of the Age of Revolutions.
A period of overseas exploration, colonization, and mercantilism in European history, lasting from the 15th to the 18th century.

A series of events that marked the emergence of modern science during the early modern period, when developments in mathematics, physics, astronomy, biology and chemistry transformed the views of society about nature.
The transition to new manufacturing processes in Europe and the United States, in the period from about 1760 to sometime between 1820 and 1840.
A colonial revolt that took place between 1765 and 1783.
A period of far-reaching social and political upheaval in France and its colonies beginning in 1789.
A series of major conflicts pitting the French Empire and its allies, led by Napoleon I, against a fluctuating array of European powers formed into various coalitions.
A civil war in the United States from 1861 to 1865, fought between the northern states and the southern states.
A period of widespread social activism and political reform across the United States that spanned the 1890s to the 1920s.
A global war originating in Europe that lasted from 28 July 1914 to 11 November 1918.

A decade of economic growth and widespread prosperity driven by recovery from wartime devastation and deferred spending, a boom in construction, and the rapid growth of consumer goods such as automobiles and electricity in North America and Europe and a few other developed countries such as Australia.
A severe worldwide economic depression that took place mostly during the 1930s, beginning in the United States.
A global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945.
A decades-long movement with the goal of securing legal rights for African Americans that other Americans already held.
A conflict in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia from 1 November 1955 to the fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975.

A historical period that began in the mid-20th century, characterized by a rapid epochal shift from traditional industry established by the Industrial Revolution to an economy primarily based upon information technology.
A series of four coordinated terrorist attacks by the Islamic terrorist group al-Qaeda against the United States on the morning of Tuesday, September 11, 2001.
An international military campaign launched by the United States government after the September 11 attacks.
A civilization of ancient North Africa, concentrated along the lower reaches of the Nile River in the place that is now the country Egypt.
A civilization belonging to a period of Greek history from the Greek Dark Ages of the 12th–9th centuries BC to the end of antiquity.
The continuation of the Roman Empire in its eastern provinces during Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages, when its capital city was Constantinople.
A state that controlled much of Southeastern Europe, Western Asia and Northern Africa between the 14th and early 20th centuries.
An empire in the Indian subcontinent, founded in 1526.
A system of colonies and other territories that were ruled by the United Kingdom and its predecessor states.
The largest contiguous land empire in history.
A Mesoamerican culture that flourished in central Mexico in the post-classic period from 1300 to 1521.
The largest empire in pre-Columbian America.

A Mesoamerican civilization developed by the Maya peoples, and noted for its logosyllabic script—the most sophisticated and highly developed writing system in pre-Columbian Americas—as well as for its art, architecture, mathematics, calendar, and astronomical system.
The period from approximately 1774 to 1849 in which a number of significant revolutionary movements occurred in most of Europe and the Americas.
A period of colonial expansion by European powers, the United States, and Japan during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
The period of time that immediately followed ancient history.

A series of conflicts in Western Europe from 1337 to 1453, waged between the House of Plantagenet and its cadet House of Lancaster, the rulers of the Kingdom of England, and the House of Valois over the right to rule the Kingdom of France.

A series of English civil wars for control of the throne of England fought between supporters of two rival cadet branches of the royal House of Plantagenet: the House of Lancaster, represented by a red rose, and the House of York, represented by a white rose.
A series of civil wars and political machinations between Parliamentarians and Royalists over, principally, the manner of England's government.
The overthrow of King James II of England by a union of English Parliamentarians with the Dutch stadtholder William III, Prince of Orange.
A Spanish fleet of 130 ships that sailed from Lisbon in late May 1588 under the command of the Duke of Medina Sidonia, with the purpose of escorting an army from Flanders to invade England.
A battle fought from July 1 to 3, 1863, in and around the town of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, by Union and Confederate forces during the American Civil War.
A surprise military strike by the Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service against the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii Territory, on the morning of December 7, 1941.
The two Japanese cities on which the United States dropped atomic bombs in 1945.
A guarded concrete barrier that physically and ideologically divided Berlin from 1961 to 1989.
A 13-day confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union initiated by the American discovery of Soviet ballistic missile deployment in Cuba.
The period in which the United States invaded Afghanistan after the September 11 attacks.
A series of anti-government protests, uprisings, and armed rebellions that spread across much of the Arab world in the early 2010s.
A bubonic plague pandemic occurring in Afro-Eurasia from 1346 to 1353.
A global pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2.

A series of events that involved the overthrow of the last monarch of Iran, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, and the replacement of his government with an Islamic republic under the Grand Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

A period of political and social revolution across the territory of the Russian Empire, commencing with the abolition of the monarchy in 1917 and concluding in 1923 with the Bolshevik establishment of the Soviet Union at the end of the Civil War.
The period between 1485 and 1603 in England and Wales and includes the Elizabethan era during the reign of Elizabeth I until 1603.
The epoch in the Tudor period of the history of England during the reign of Queen Elizabeth I.
The period in English and Scottish history that coincides with the reign of James VI of Scotland who also inherited the crown of England in 1603 as James I.
The period of British history between 1603 and 1714.
A period in British history from 1714 to c. 1830–37, named after the Hanoverian Kings George I, George II, George III and George IV.
The period at the end of the Georgian era, when King George III was deemed unfit to rule due to his illness, and his son ruled as his proxy, as Prince Regent.
The period of British history covering the reign of King Edward VII, 1901 to 1910.
The period between the end of the First World War and the beginning of the Second World War.
The nationwide constitutional ban on the production, importation, transportation, and sale of alcoholic beverages from 1920 to 1933 in the United States.
A treaty which led to the creation of Europe's Schengen Area, in which internal border checks have largely been abolished.
The most important of the peace treaties that brought World War I to an end.
A meeting of the heads of government of the United States, the United Kingdom, and the Soviet Union to discuss the postwar reorganization of Germany and Europe.
A meeting of the heads of government of the United States, the United Kingdom, and the Soviet Union to discuss the postwar order, peace treaty issues, and countering the effects of the war.
An American initiative to aid Western Europe, in which the United States gave over $12 billion in economic assistance to help rebuild Western European economies after the end of World War II.
A collective defense treaty signed in Warsaw, Poland among the Soviet Union and seven Soviet satellite states of Central and Eastern Europe during the Cold War.
An intergovernmental organisation founded on 10 January 1920 as a result of the Paris Peace Conference that ended the First World War.
An armed revolt conducted by Fidel Castro's revolutionary 26th of July Movement and its allies against the authoritarian government of Cuban President Fulgencio Batista.
A political movement for reformation within the Communist Party of the Soviet Union during the 1980s and is widely associated with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and his glasnost policy reform.
Student-led demonstrations held in Tiananmen Square in Beijing during 1989.
A pivotal event in world history which marked the falling of the Iron Curtain and the start of the fall of communism in Eastern and Central Europe.

An international treaty which extends the 1992 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change that commits state parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, based on the scientific consensus that global warming is occurring and that human-made CO₂ emissions are driving it.
An agreement within the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, on climate change mitigation, adaptation, and finance, signed in 2016.
A period of European history in which monarchs successfully gathered the wealth and power of the state to themselves.
A movement in the 18th century that advocated the use of reason in the reappraisal of accepted ideas and social institutions.
A period of Western history. It is conventionally dated from the end of the Franco-Prussian War in 1871 to the outbreak of World War I in 1914.
The socioeconomic shift in which the Western world overcame pre-modern growth constraints and emerged during the 19th century as the most powerful and wealthy world civilization.

The period of Mediterranean history between the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC and the emergence of the Roman Empire as signified by the Battle of Actium in 31 BC and the subsequent conquest of Ptolemaic Egypt the following year.

The wide-scale transition of many human cultures during the Neolithic period from a lifestyle of hunting and gathering to one of agriculture and settlement, making an increasingly large population possible.
The economic and/or cultural state or condition of society which is said to exist after modernity.
An era in ancient Chinese history characterized by warfare, as well as bureaucratic and military reforms and consolidation.
An event that restored practical imperial rule to Japan in 1868 under Emperor Meiji.
A period in Japanese history of nearly constant civil war, social upheaval, and political intrigue from 1467 to 1603.
A period of cultural, economic and scientific flourishing in the history of Islam, traditionally dated from the 8th century to the 14th century.
An economic policy that is designed to maximize the exports and minimize the imports for an economy.
The widespread transfer of plants, animals, culture, human populations, technology, and ideas between the Americas, West Africa, and the Old World in the 15th and 16th centuries.
The trade between historical civilizations in Asia, Northeast Africa and Europe.
A multilateral system of trading in which a country pays for its imports from one country by its exports to another.
A sub-discipline of history that studies the working class, the labor movement, and the social, cultural, and political impact of work.
The academic study of economies or economic events of the past.
A field of history that looks at the lived experience of the past.
The study of the history of human thought and of intellectuals, people who conceptualize, discuss, write about, and concern themselves with ideas.
The study of political events, ideas, movements, and leaders.

gameData.description: Instruments from various families, including string, brass, woodwind, and percussion.

easy.hint: A stringed musical instrument with a thin membrane stretched over a frame or cavity as a resonator, called the head.
A bowed string instrument of the violin family. Its four strings are usually tuned in perfect fifths: from low to high, C₂, G₂, D₃ and A₃.
A percussion instrument sounded by being struck with sticks or the hands, typically cylindrical, barrel-shaped, or bowl-shaped with a taut membrane over one or both ends.

A two-stringed bowed musical instrument, more specifically a spike fiddle, which may also be called a 'southern fiddle', and sometimes known in the Western world as the 'Chinese violin' or a 'Chinese two-stringed fiddle'.
A woodwind instrument made of a tube with holes along it that are stopped by the fingers or keys, held vertically or horizontally so that the player's breath strikes a narrow edge.
A genre of music that is traditionally passed down from generation to generation.
A stringed musical instrument which has a number of individual strings running at an angle to its soundboard; the strings are plucked with the fingers.
A music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana, United States, in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
A Japanese plucked half-tube zither instrument, and the national instrument of Japan.
A large keyboard musical instrument with a wooden case enclosing a soundboard and metal strings, which are struck by hammers when the keys are depressed.
A genre of popular music that originated in the West during the 1950s and 1960s.
A rock music genre that emerged in the mid-1970s in the United States, United Kingdom, and Australia.
A broad genre of popular music that originated as 'rock and roll' in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s.
A plucked stringed instrument, originating from the Indian subcontinent, used in Hindustani classical music.
A popular music genre that originated in the African American community throughout the United States in the 1950s and early 1960s.
A simple brass instrument, having no valves or other pitch-altering devices.
A percussion instrument originating in East and Southeast Asia.
A stringed musical instrument that has a number of individual strings running at an angle to its soundboard; the strings are plucked with the fingers.
Any plucked string instrument with a neck and a deep round back enclosing a hollow cavity, usually with a sound hole or opening in the body.
A type of double reed woodwind instrument.
A plucked stringed instrument, originating from the Indian subcontinent, used in Hindustani classical music.

normal.hint: A portable free-reed musical instrument.
A musical instrument from Indonesia made of a varying number of bamboo tubes attached to a bamboo frame.
A wind instrument using enclosed reeds fed from a constant reservoir of air in the form of a bag.
A gourd-resonated xylophone, a type of struck idiophone. It is closely associated with the Mandé peoples of West Africa.
A Russian stringed musical instrument with a characteristic triangular wooden, hollow body, fretted neck and three strings.

A music genre and musical form which was originated in the Deep South of the United States around the 1860s by African-Americans from roots in African musical traditions, African-American work songs, and spirituals.
A single-reed woodwind instrument with a cylindrical tube, a flared bell, and a single-reed mouthpiece.
Art music produced or rooted in the traditions of Western culture, including both liturgical and secular music.
A genre of popular music that originated in the southern United States in the early 1920s.
A wind instrument, played with continuously vibrating lips to produce a continuous drone while using a special breathing technique called circular breathing.
A rope-tuned skin-covered goblet drum played with bare hands, originally from West Africa.
An electronic musical instrument that creates percussion sounds, drum beats, and patterns.
Music that employs electronic musical instruments, digital instruments, or circuitry-based music technology in its creation.

A music genre that originated in African-American communities in the mid-1960s when musicians created a rhythmic, danceable new form of music through a mixture of soul music, jazz, and rhythm and blues (R&B).
A stringed musical instrument with a fretted fingerboard, typically incurved sides, and six or twelve strings, played by plucking or strumming with the fingers or a plectrum.
A Chinese plucked zither.
A free reed wind instrument used worldwide in many musical genres, notably in blues, American folk music, classical music, jazz, country, and rock and roll.
A genre of music that originated in the Bronx borough of New York City in the 1970s.
Any plucked string instrument with a neck and a deep round back enclosing a hollow cavity, usually with a sound hole or opening in the body.
A stringed musical instrument in the lute family and is usually plucked with a plectrum.
An electro-mechanical, polyphonic tape replay keyboard.
A genre of rock music that developed in the late 1960s and early 1970s, largely in the United Kingdom and the United States.
A music genre that originated in Jamaica in the late 1960s.

An electronic or digital musical instrument which uses sound recordings (or 'samples') of real instrument sounds (e.g., a piano, violin or trumpet), excerpts from recorded songs (e.g., a five-second bass guitar riff from a funk song) or found sounds (e.g., sirens and ocean waves).
A member of a family of single-reed woodwind instruments with a conical body, usually of brass.
A three-stringed traditional Japanese musical instrument derived from the Chinese instrument sanxian.
An electronic musical instrument controlled without physical contact by the thereminist (performer).
A brass instrument consisting of a long cylindrical tube bent upon itself twice, ending in a bell-shaped mouth, and having a movable slide for varying the pitch.
A brass instrument commonly used in classical and jazz ensembles.
A small four-stringed guitar of Hawaiian origin.
A stringed musical instrument of treble pitch, played with a horsehair bow.
A musical instrument in the percussion family that consists of wooden bars struck by mallets.
A box-shaped musical instrument that is played by stretching and squeezing it with the arms and pressing buttons or keys with the fingers.
A wind instrument with reed pipes that are sounded by the pressure of wind stored in a bag, which is squeezed by the player's arm.
A stringed musical instrument with a thin membrane stretched over a frame or cavity to form a resonator.
A large drum that produces a note of low definite or indefinite pitch.
A musical instrument of the clarinet family.
A woodwind instrument in the double reed family that plays music written in the bass and tenor clefs, and occasionally the treble.
A hollow, cup-shaped acoustic resonator which vibrates when struck.
A pair of concave shells joined on one edge by a string, held in the hand and rattled together.
A keyboard instrument in which the notes are produced by hammers striking metal bars.
A bowed, and sometimes plucked, string instrument with four strings tuned in perfect fifths.
A set of tuned bells, especially one in a clock tower.
A family of woodwind instruments.
A European stringed keyboard instrument known from the late Medieval, through the Renaissance, Baroque and Classical eras.
A tall, narrow, single-headed drum from Cuba.
A brass instrument similar to the trumpet but distinguished from it by its conical bore, more compact shape, and mellower tone quality.
A common percussion instrument.
A wind instrument developed by Indigenous Australians of northern Australia around 1,500 years ago and still in widespread use today both in Australia and around the world.

A collection of drums and other percussion instruments, typically cymbals, which are set up on stands to be played by a single player, with drumsticks held in both hands and the feet operating pedals that control the hi-hat cymbal and the beater for the bass drum.
A stringed instrument of the zither family.
A guitar that requires external amplification in order to be heard at typical performance volumes.
An electronic musical instrument, an electronic or digital derivative of an acoustic piano.
A conical-bore, baritone-voiced brass instrument that derives its name from the Ancient Greek word εὔφωνος, meaning 'well-sounding' or 'sweet-voiced'.
A bowed string musical instrument, most often a violin.
A brass instrument that resembles the trumpet and cornet but has a wider, more conical bore.
A family of musical instruments in the woodwind group.
A percussion instrument composed of a set of tuned keys arranged in the fashion of the keyboard of a piano.
A fretted musical instrument that usually has six strings.
A free reed wind instrument used worldwide in many musical genres, notably in blues, American folk music, classical music, jazz, country, and rock and roll.
A type of free-reed organ that generates sound as air flows past a vibrating piece of thin metal in a frame.
A combination of two cymbals and a pedal, all mounted on a metal stand.
A stringed instrument that produces sound by a hand crank-turned, rosined wheel rubbing against the strings.
A lamellophone instrument, which is in the category of plucked idiophones.
A musical instrument from Africa.
An American musical instrument that adds a 'buzzing' timbral quality to a player's voice when the player vocalizes into it.
A type of drum, consisting of a membrane called a head stretched over a large bowl traditionally made of copper.
A set of adjacent depressible levers or keys on a musical instrument.
A string instrument known for its use in Greek classical antiquity and later periods.
A stringed musical instrument in the lute family and is usually plucked with a plectrum or 'pick'.
A rattle which appears in many genres of Caribbean and Latin music.
A percussion instrument consisting of a set of wooden bars struck with mallets to produce musical tones.
A free-reed instrument similar to a pump organ or harmonica.
A type of vessel flute.
A keyboard instrument of one or more pipe divisions or other means for producing tones, each played with its own keyboard, played either with the hands on a keyboard or with the feet on pedals.
A musical instrument based on the principle of the closed tube, consisting of multiple pipes of gradually increasing length.
An acoustic, stringed musical instrument invented in Italy by Bartolomeo Cristofori around the year 1700.
A half-size flute, and a member of the woodwind family of musical instruments.
A musical instrument that produces sound by driving pressurized air through organ pipes selected via a keyboard.
A family of woodwind musical instruments in the group known as internal duct flutes—flutes with a whistle mouthpiece, also known as fipple flutes.
A family of woodwind instruments.
A percussion instrument that produces a sharp staccato sound when the head is struck with a drum stick, due to the use of a series of stiff wires held under tension against the lower skin.
A brass instrument in the same family as the tuba.
A musical instrument originating from Trinidad and Tobago.
A musical instrument in the percussion family consisting of a frame, often of wood or plastic, with pairs of small metal jingles, called 'zills'.
An electronic musical instrument controlled without physical contact by the thereminist.
Musical instruments in the percussion family.
An idiophone type of musical instrument in the percussion family.
A musical instrument in the brass family.
A brass instrument commonly used in classical and jazz ensembles.
The largest and lowest-pitched musical instrument in the brass family.
A member of the lute family of instruments.
A musical instrument in the struck idiophone subfamily of the percussion family.
A string instrument that is bowed or played with varying techniques.
A wooden string instrument in the violin family.
A plastic horn, about 65 centimetres long, which produces a loud, monotonous note.
A tool used for washing clothes.
A stringed instrument used in American folk music that uses a metal washtub as a resonator.
An instrument which produces sound from a stream of gas, most commonly air.
A musical instrument in the percussion family that consists of wooden bars struck by mallets.
A class of stringed instruments.

difficult.hint: A fretted string instrument of the zither family, typically with three or four strings, originally played in the Appalachian region of the United States.
A hand-crafted modern musical instrument with a unique harp- or bell-like sound. It is a radical redesign of the African mbira.
A plucked string instrument similar in appearance and construction to an electric guitar, except with a longer neck and scale length, and typically four to six strings.
A type of electronic keyboard instrument designed to serve primarily as an alternative to the traditional acoustic piano, both in the way it feels to play and in the sound produced.
A guitar that requires external amplification in order to be heard at typical performance volumes.
A digital synthesizer, sampler and digital audio workstation introduced in 1979 by the Australian company Fairlight.
A type of musical instrument that uses a series of glass bowls or goblets graduated in size to produce musical tones by means of friction.
An early electronic musical instrument.
A genre of popular music that originated in African-American communities in the 1940s.
An electronic musical instrument that generates audio signals.
A guitar that produces sound acoustically by transmitting the vibration of the strings to the air.
A low-pitched brass instrument in the saxhorn family.
A stringed instrument played primarily with the fingers or thumb, by plucking, slapping, popping, strumming, tapping, thumping, or picking with a plectrum or pick.
An Afro-Cuban percussion instrument consisting of a pair of small open-bottomed drums of different sizes.
A larger version of the bassoon, sounding an octave lower.
The largest and lowest-pitched bowed string instrument in the modern symphony orchestra.
An electronic musical instrument that can imitate drum kits and percussion instruments.
An electronic keyboard instrument which was derived from the harmonium, pipe organ and theatre organ.
A double-reed woodwind instrument in the oboe family.
A brass instrument made of tubing wrapped into a coil with a flared bell.
A large piano, the strings of which are set in a frame that is raised on three legs.
A musical instrument played by means of a keyboard.
A synthesizer developed by the American engineer Robert Moog.
A simple, six-holed woodwind instrument.
A wind instrument consisting of a fipple and a tube with a piston in it.
An electronic musical instrument that generates audio signals.
Musical instruments in the percussion family.
A piano in which the frame and strings are vertical.

gameData.description: Creatures from myths, legends, and folklore.

easy.hint: A steed from the heavens that transported the prophets in Islamic tradition.

A type of mythical being or legendary creature found in the folklore of multiple European cultures (including Celtic, Slavic, German, English, and French folklore), a form of spirit, often described as metaphysical, supernatural, or preternatural.
A diminutive spirit in Renaissance magic and alchemy, first introduced by Paracelsus in the 16th century and later adopted by more recent authors including those of modern fantasy literature.
An animated anthropomorphic being in Jewish folklore which is created entirely from inanimate matter (usually clay or mud).
A serpentine water monster in Greek and Roman mythology.
A yōkai demon or imp found in traditional Japanese folklore.
A sacred bull calf, gatekeeper, and vehicle of the Hindu god Shiva.
A half-human, half-goat creature from Greek mythology.
A type of legendary creature found in Japanese folk religion and are also considered a type of yōkai or Shinto kami (gods).

normal.hint: The foster-mother of Zeus, sometimes represented as a goat.
A hundred-eyed giant in Greek mythology.
An immortal horse in Greek mythology, which was very fast and endowed with speech.
A female spirit in Irish folklore who heralds the death of a family member, usually by wailing, shrieking, or keening.
A creature from Greek mythology with the upper body of a human and the lower body and legs of a horse.
A multi-headed dog, or 'hellhound' with a serpent's tail, a mane of snakes, and a lion's claws.
A mythical creature that lived in Ceryneia, Greece. It was a sacred deer of Artemis, the goddess of the hunt.
A monstrous fire-breathing hybrid creature of Lycia in Asia Minor, composed of the parts of more than one animal.
The brother of the winged horse Pegasus, Chrysaor is the offspring of Poseidon and the Gorgon Medusa.
A legendary creature in the folklore of parts of the Americas, with its first purported sightings reported in Puerto Rico in 1995.
A member of a primordial race of giants, each with a single eye in the middle of his forehead.
A member of a primordial race of giants, each with a single eye in the middle of his forehead.
A monstrous she-dragon.
A large, serpent-like legendary creature that appears in the folklore of many cultures around the world.
A monster, half-woman and half-snake, who lived alone in a cave. She was the mate of the fearsome monster Typhon and was the mother of most of the major monsters of Greek mythology.
A mythical creature that lived on Mount Erymanthos.
A half-human, half-goat creature from Roman mythology.
A race of great strength and aggression, though not necessarily of great size, known for the Gigantomachy, their battle with the Olympian gods.

A female creature in Greek mythology. While descriptions of Gorgons vary across Greek literature, the term commonly refers to any of three sisters who had hair made of living, venomous snakes, as well as a horrifying visage that turned those who beheld her to stone.
Three monstrous sisters, Stheno, Euryale, and Medusa. They had hair of living, venomous snakes, and a horrifying visage that turned those who beheld her to stone.
A character in the Anglo-Saxon epic poem Beowulf.
A legendary creature with the body, tail, and back legs of a lion; the head and wings of an eagle; and an eagle's talons as its front feet.
A female monster in the form of a bird with a human face.
A legendary creature said to inhabit the Pine Barrens of Southern New Jersey.
A shape-shifting water spirit inhabiting the lochs and pools of Scotland.
The Japanese word for fox. In English, kitsune refers to them in the context of Japanese folklore.
A legendary cephalopod-like sea monster of giant size in Scandinavian folklore.
A divine dog in Greek mythology that was destined to catch everything it pursued.
A type of fairy in Irish folklore.
A legendary aquatic creature with the head and upper body of a female human and the tail of a fish.
A creature from Greek mythology who was a monster with the body of a man and the head and tail of a bull.
A humanoid creature reportedly seen in the Point Pleasant area of West Virginia from November 15, 1966, to December 15, 1967.
A kind of yōkai, demon, ogre, or troll in Japanese folklore.
A female monster from Colombian folklore that lives in the jungle.
A mythical winged divine stallion, and one of the most recognized creatures in Greek mythology.
A long-lived bird that cyclically regenerates or is otherwise born again.
A simian-like creature of American folklore that is said to inhabit forests, especially in the Pacific Northwest.
A creature in Greek mythology who lured sailors with their enchanting music and singing voices to shipwreck on the rocky coast of their island.
A mythical creature with the head of a human, the body of a lion, and the wings of a falcon.
A class of being in Norse mythology and Scandinavian folklore.
The deadliest monster in Greek mythology. Typhon was the last son of Gaia, fathered by Tartarus, and is considered the 'Father of All Monsters'.
A legendary creature that has been described since antiquity as a beast with a single large, pointed, spiraling horn projecting from its forehead.
A composite monster with the head of an ox and the body of a spider from Japanese folklore.
A creature from folklore that subsists by feeding on the vital essence (generally in the form of blood) of the living.

A mythological or folkloric human with the ability to shapeshift into a wolf or a therianthropic hybrid wolf-like creature, either purposely or after being placed under a curse or affliction (often a bite or scratch from another werewolf).
An ape-like creature purported to inhabit the Himalayan mountain range in Asia.
A fictional undead corporeal revenant created through the reanimation of a corpse.

difficult.hint: The Meliae were nymphs of the ash tree, born from the blood of Uranus.
The bull that fathered the Minotaur.
Three giants of incredible strength and ferocity that surpassed all of the Titans, whom they helped overthrow.
A race of people living on an island dominated by lotus plants.
A shape-shifting witch from the Navajo tradition.

gameData.description: Celestial bodies in our solar system and beyond.

easy.hint: The third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life.
The fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet in the Solar System, being larger than only Mercury.
A prominent constellation located on the celestial equator and visible throughout the world.
The second planet from the Sun. It is named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty.

normal.hint: One of the 48 constellations listed by the 2nd-century Greco-Roman astronomer Ptolemy, and one of the 88 modern constellations.
A constellation on the celestial equator. Its name is Latin for 'eagle' and it represents the bird that carried Zeus's/Jupiter's thunderbolts in Greco-Roman mythology.
A planetary nebula in the constellation Vulpecula, at a distance of about 1,360 light-years.
A region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from it.
A constellation in the northern sky, named after the vain queen Cassiopeia in Greek mythology, who boasted about her unrivaled beauty.
A northern constellation lying on the plane of the Milky Way, deriving its name from the Latinized Greek word for swan.
The fifth planet from the Sun and the largest in the Solar System.
A small constellation. It is one of 48 listed by the 2nd-century astronomer Ptolemy, and is one of the 88 constellations recognized by the International Astronomical Union.
The smallest and innermost planet in the Solar System.
An interstellar cloud of dust, hydrogen, helium and other ionized gases.
The eighth and farthest-known Solar planet from the Sun.
A constellation in the northern sky, named after the winged horse Pegasus in Greek mythology.
An open star cluster containing middle-aged, hot B-type stars located in the constellation of Taurus.
A dwarf planet in the Kuiper belt, a ring of bodies beyond the orbit of Neptune.
A highly magnetized rotating neutron star that emits beams of electromagnetic radiation out of its magnetic poles.
An extremely luminous active galactic nucleus, in which a supermassive black hole with mass ranging from millions to billions of times the mass of the Sun is surrounded by a gaseous accretion disk.
The sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest in the Solar System, after Jupiter.
A powerful and luminous stellar explosion.
Earth's only natural satellite.
The star at the center of the Solar System.
The seventh planet from the Sun. It has the third-largest planetary radius and fourth-largest planetary mass in the Solar System.
A constellation in the northern sky, whose associated mythology likely dates back into prehistory.
A constellation in the Northern Sky.

difficult.hint: A barred spiral galaxy approximately 2.5 million light-years from Earth and the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way.
A barred irregular galaxy in the constellation Sagittarius.
A supernova remnant in the constellation of Taurus.
A short-period comet visible from Earth every 75–76 years.
The collapsed core of a giant star which before collapse had a total of between 10 and 29 solar masses.

A torus-shaped region in the Solar System, located roughly between the orbits of the planets Jupiter and Mars, that is occupied by a great many solid, irregularly shaped bodies, of many sizes but much smaller than planets, called asteroids or minor planets.
The galaxy that contains our Solar System.

gameData.description: Jobs and careers that people have.

easy.hint: A person whose profession is acting on the stage, in movies, or on television.
A person who makes bread and cakes, especially as a trade.
A professional cook and tradesman who is proficient in all aspects of food preparation, often focusing on a particular cuisine.
A public official appointed to decide cases in a court of law.
A person trained to care for the sick or infirm, especially in a hospital.
A person who operates the flying controls of an aircraft.

normal.hint: A person who keeps or inspects financial accounts.
An artist who creates multiple images, known as frames, which give an illusion of movement called animation when displayed in rapid sequence.
A person who designs buildings and in many cases also supervises their construction.
A person who creates paintings or drawings as a profession or hobby.
A person who is trained to travel in a spacecraft.
A person appointed to act for another in business or legal matters.
A person who works in a bank.
A person who drives a taxi.
The person in command of a ship.
A doctor who specializes in the study or treatment of heart diseases and heart abnormalities.
A person who writes music, especially as a professional occupation.
A person who conducts an orchestra, choir, opera company, ballet, or other musical group in the performance and interpretation of ensemble works.
A person who mixes recorded music for an audience.
A person who dances or whose profession is dancing.
A person who is qualified to treat diseases and other conditions that affect the teeth and gums, especially the repair and extraction of teeth and the insertion of artificial ones.
A person whose immediate subordinate is a senior figure in an organization, and who is empowered to act as a substitute for this superior.
A person who is qualified to treat people who are ill.
An expert in or student of ecology.
An expert in economics.
A person who is in charge of and determines the final content of a text, particularly a newspaper or magazine.
A person who provides instruction or education; a teacher.
A person who designs, builds, or maintains engines, machines, or public works.
A person who keeps, trains, or hunts with falcons, hawks, or other birds of prey.
A person who cultivates land and raises livestock.
A person concerned with the management of large amounts of money on behalf of governments or other large organizations.
A person who tends and cultivates a garden as a pastime or for a living.
A person who is skilled at a wide range of repairs, typically around the home.
A person who practices or studies law; an attorney or a counselor.
A skilled worker who repairs and maintains machinery.
A person who plays a musical instrument, especially as a profession, or is musically talented.
A person who is trained to do medical work, especially in an emergency, but who is not a fully qualified doctor.
A person who is professionally qualified to prepare and dispense medicinal drugs.
A person who makes photographs.
A person who installs and repairs the pipes and fittings of water supply, sanitation, or heating systems.
An expert or specialist in psychology.
A person who is studying or has expert knowledge of one or more of the natural or physical sciences.
A person who sings, especially professionally.
A medical practitioner qualified to practice surgery.
A person who teaches, especially in a school.
A person who has written a particular text, or whose profession is writing.

difficult.hint: A person who directs aircraft on the ground and through a given section of controlled airspace, and can provide advisory services to aircraft in non-controlled airspace.
A practitioner of the system of complementary medicine based on the diagnosis and manipulative treatment of misalignments of the joints.
A manual laborer who works on a construction site.
A medical practitioner qualified to diagnose and treat skin disorders.
A person who installs and maintains electrical equipment.
A person who designs clothing.
A person who extinguishes fires.
A person who designs games.
A person who collects refuse from households and businesses.
A professional within the graphic design and graphic arts industry who assembles together images, typography, or motion graphics to create a piece of design.
A person who cuts and styles hair as an occupation.
Someone who plans, researches, coordinates, and manages such projects.
A person who practices optometry.
A warranted law employee of a police force.
A medical practitioner specializing in the diagnosis and treatment of mental illness.
A medical doctor who is trained in executing and interpreting medical images such as X-rays, CT scans, ultrasounds, and MRIs and using them to treat health problems in patients.
A person qualified to treat diseased or injured animals.

easy.hint: A club-and-ball sport in which players use various clubs to hit balls into a series of holes on a course in as few strokes as possible.
A sport in which small missiles are thrown at a circular target fixed to a wall.
A modern martial art, combat and Olympic sport created in Japan in 1882 by Jigoro Kano.
A team sport played on horseback.
A contact team sport which originated in England in the first half of the 19th century.
A group of physical, mental, and spiritual practices or disciplines which originated in ancient India.
A Soviet martial art, an internationally-practised combat sport, and a recognized style of amateur wrestling.
A hard and soft and complete martial art, as well as a full-contact sport.

normal.hint: An American retired auto racing driver. He is the only driver to win the Indianapolis 500, the Daytona 500, the 24 Hours of Daytona, and the 24 Hours of Le Mans.
The art, sport, practice, or skill of using a bow to shoot arrows.
A bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding.
A game played between two teams of five players in which goals are scored by throwing a ball through a netted hoop fixed above each end of the court.
A winter sport that combines cross-country skiing and rifle shooting.
A winter sport in which teams of two or four teammates make timed runs down narrow, twisting, banked, iced tracks in a gravity-powered sled.
A combat sport in which two people, usually wearing protective gloves, throw punches at each other for a predetermined amount of time in a boxing ring.
A sport or recreational activity which involves paddling a canoe with a single-bladed paddle.
A Scottish rally driver from Lanark, Scotland. The 1995 World Rally Championship drivers' title was his.

A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players on a field at the centre of which is a 20-metre (22-yard) pitch with a wicket at each end, each comprising two bails balanced on three stumps.
A sport in which players slide stones on a sheet of ice toward a target area which is segmented into four concentric circles.
The use of bicycles for transport, recreation, exercise or sport.
A combined event in athletics consisting of ten track and field events.
The sport of jumping or falling into water from a platform or springboard, usually while performing acrobatics.
A group of three related combat sports.
A track and field event in which a heavy ball attached to a wire and handle is thrown for distance.
A Finnish retired world champion rally driver. He was a seven-time winner of the 1000 Lakes Rally in Finland and won the RAC Rally in Great Britain four times.
A combined event in athletics consisting of seven track and field events.
A track and field event in which competitors must jump unaided over a horizontal bar placed at measured heights without dislodging it.
A contact team sport played on ice, usually in a rink, in which two teams of skaters use their sticks to shoot a vulcanized rubber puck into their opponent's net to score goals.
The self-propulsion of a person across a sheet of ice, using metal-bladed ice skates to glide on the ice surface.
An American former professional stock car racing driver, who is an inductee into the NASCAR Hall of Fame.
An American professional auto racing driver who competes in the NTT IndyCar Series.
The use of a kayak for moving across water.
A track and field event in which athletes combine speed, strength and agility in an attempt to leap as far as possible from a take off point.
A winter sport in which a competitor or two-person team rides a flat sled while lying supine (face up) and feet first.
A retired Italian-American racing driver, one of the most successful Americans in the history of the sport.
A retired German racing driver who competed in Formula One for Jordan, Benetton, Ferrari, and Mercedes.
A track and field event in which a person uses a long, flexible pole as an aid to jump over a bar.
An American former stock car racing driver who raced from 1958 to 1992 in the former NASCAR Grand National and Winston Cup Series.
The sport or activity of propelling a boat by means of oars.
A close-contact team sport that originated in England in the first half of the 19th century.
The art of controlling a boat so that it is propelled by the force of the wind on its sails.
A track and field event involving 'putting' (pushing rather than throwing) a heavy spherical object—the shot—as far as possible.
A winter sliding sport in which a person rides a small sled, known as a skeleton bobsled (or -sleigh), down a frozen track while lying face down and head-first.
A means of transport using skis to glide on snow.
A recreational activity and Olympic and Paralympic sport that involves descending a snow-covered slope while standing on a snowboard attached to a rider's feet.
A game played by two teams of eleven players with a round ball that may not be touched with the hands or arms during play except by the goalkeepers.
A competitive form of ice skating in which the competitors race each other in travelling a certain distance on skates.
Running over a short distance at the top-most speed of the body in a limited period of time.
A surface water sport in which the wave rider, referred to as a surfer, rides on the forward or deep face of a moving wave, which is usually carrying the surfer towards the shore.
An individual or team racing sport that requires the use of one's entire body to move through water.
A hybrid form of swimming, dance, and gymnastics, consisting of swimmers performing a synchronized routine of elaborate moves in the water, accompanied by music.
A racket sport that can be played individually against a single opponent (singles) or between two teams of two players each (doubles).
A team sport in which two teams of six players are separated by a net.
A German rally and racing driver, with wins for Fiat, Opel, Lancia and Audi.
A competitive team sport played in water between two teams.
The sport, practice or skill of using a bow to propel arrows.
A racquet sport played using racquets to hit a shuttlecock across a net.
A bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding.

A team sport in which two teams, most commonly of five players each, opposing one another on a rectangular court, compete with the primary objective of shooting a basketball through the defender's hoop while preventing the opposing team from shooting through their own hoop.
A target sport and recreational activity in which a player rolls a ball toward pins or another target.
A combat sport in which two people, usually wearing protective gloves, throw punches at each other for a predetermined amount of time in a boxing ring.
A sport or recreational activity which involves paddling a canoe with a single-bladed paddle.
A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players on a field at the centre of which is a 20-metre pitch with a wicket at each end, each comprising two bails balanced on three stumps.
A sport in which players slide stones on a sheet of ice towards a target area which is segmented into four concentric circles.
The use of bicycles for transport, recreation, exercise or sport.
The sport of jumping or falling into water from a platform or springboard, usually while performing acrobatics.
A sport in which two competitors fight using swords, winning points by making contact with their opponent.
The activity of trying to catch fish.
A family of team sports that involve, to varying degrees, kicking a ball to score a goal.
A club-and-ball sport in which players use various clubs to hit balls into a series of holes on a course in as few strokes as possible.
A sport that includes physical exercises requiring balance, strength, flexibility, agility, coordination, and endurance.
A team sport in which two teams of seven players each pass a ball using their hands with the aim of throwing it into the goal of the other team.
A sport in which two teams play against each other by trying to maneuver a ball or a puck into the opponent's goal using a hockey stick.
A martial art developed in the Ryukyu Kingdom.
The use of a kayak for moving across water.
A team sport played with a lacrosse stick and a lacrosse ball.

Codified systems and traditions of combat practices, which are practiced for a number of reasons: as self-defense, military and law enforcement applications, mental and spiritual development; as well as entertainment and the preservation of a nation's intangible cultural heritage.
A full-contact combat sport that allows striking and grappling, both standing and on the ground, using techniques from other combat sports and martial arts.
A global term used to encompass the group of competitive sporting events which primarily involve the use of motorized vehicles, whether for racing or non-racing competition.
A ball sport played by two teams of seven players.
A sport whose origins reach back to Ancient Egyptian times.
The sport of using wind to power sailboats and propel them across the water.
The act or process of discharging a projectile from a ranged weapon.
A means of transport using skis to glide on snow.
A cue sport that is played on a baize-covered table with pockets in each of the four corners and in the middle of each of the long side cushions.
A team sport played with a ball between two teams of 11 players.
A variant of baseball played with a larger ball on a smaller field.
A racquet sport played by two or four players in a four-walled court with a small, hollow rubber ball.
A form of competitive full-contact wrestling where a rikishi attempts to force another wrestler out of a circular ring or into touching the ground with anything other than the soles of his feet.
A surface water sport in which the wave rider, referred to as a surfer, rides on the forward or deep face of a moving wave, which is usually carrying the surfer towards the shore.
The self-propulsion of a person through water, or other liquid, usually for recreation, sport, exercise, or survival.
A sport in which two or four players hit a lightweight ball back and forth across a table using small rackets.
A Korean martial art, characterized by its emphasis on head-height kicks, jumping and spinning kicks, and fast kicking techniques.
A racket sport that can be played individually against a single opponent or between two teams of two players each.
A device consisting of a piece of taut, strong fabric stretched between a steel frame using many coiled springs.
A multiple-stage competition involving the completion of three continuous and sequential endurance disciplines.
A non-contact team sport played with a frisbee.
A team sport in which two teams of six players are separated by a net.
A competitive team sport played in water between two teams of seven players each.
A combat sport involving grappling-type techniques such as clinch fighting, throws and takedowns, joint locks, pins and other grappling holds.
A contact sport played between two teams of eighteen players on an oval-shaped field, often a modified cricket ground.
A team sport played by two teams of two players on a sand court divided by a net.
A competitive ball sport played on water in a defined area between two teams of five players, each in a kayak.
A surface water sport in which an individual is pulled behind a boat or a cable ski installation over a body of water, skimming the surface on two skis or one ski.
A modern Japanese martial art developed by Morihei Ueshiba as a synthesis of his martial studies, philosophy, and religious beliefs.
An Afro-Brazilian martial art that combines elements of dance, acrobatics, and music.

A military self-defence and fighting system developed for the Israel Defense Forces and Israeli security forces that consists of a combination of techniques sourced from aikido, boxing, wrestling, judo, and karate.
A number of fighting styles that have developed over the centuries in China.
A combat sport of Thailand that uses stand-up striking along with various clinching techniques.
A French combat sport that uses the hands and feet as weapons combining elements of English boxing with graceful kicking techniques.
A sport with two opponents who face each other with their bent elbows placed on a table.
Competitive ballroom dancing, as contrasted to social or exhibition dancing.
A table-top game that is loosely based on association football.
A martial game or hastilude between two horsemen wielding lances with blunted tips, often as part of a tournament.
A ball sport, with similarities to netball and basketball.
A winter sport in which a competitor or two-person team rides a flat sled while lying supine and feet first.
A winter sport in which teams of two or four make timed runs down narrow, twisting, banked, iced tracks in a gravity-powered sled.
A winter sliding sport in which a person rides a small sled, known as a skeleton bobsled, down a frozen track while lying face down and head-first.
A style of folk wrestling native to Switzerland.
The oldest tennis tournament in the world, and is widely regarded as the most prestigious.
An annual tennis tournament held in Queens, New York.
The annual championship game of the National Football League.
The championship series of the National Basketball Association.
The championship trophy awarded annually to the National Hockey League playoff winner.
A Test cricket series played between England and Australia.
A biennial men's golf competition between teams from Europe and the United States.
A smooth wooden or metal club used in the sport of baseball to hit the ball after it is thrown by the pitcher.
A horizontal circular metal hoop supporting a net through which players try to score points by throwing a basketball.
A hard, spherical ball used to knock down bowling pins.
A specialised piece of equipment used by batsmen in the sport of cricket to hit the ball.
A hard, solid ball used to play cricket.
An item of sporting equipment essential to the games of pool, snooker and carom billiards.
A circular target for the game of darts.
A heavy thick-centered disk thrown by an athlete, in ancient Greek games or in modern field events.
A short bar with a weight at each end, used in pairs for exercise or muscle-building.
A gliding toy or sporting item that is generally plastic and roughly 20 to 25 centimetres in diameter with a lip, used recreationally and competitively for throwing and catching.
A small four-wheeled vehicle.
A pair of upright posts connected by a crossbar and forming a goal.
A bag for carrying golf clubs.
A special ball designed to be used in the game of golf.
A club used to hit a golf ball in a game of golf.
An apparatus in gymnastics.
A small, round bag filled with sand or plastic pellets, which is kicked into the air as part of a game.
The final base that a player must touch to score a run in baseball or softball.
A U-shaped item made of metal, thrown in a game, to encircle a stake.
A barrier that athletes must jump over in a race.
Boots with blades attached to the bottom, used for skating on ice.
A light spear designed to be thrown as a weapon or for sport.
The traditional uniform worn for Judo practice and competition.
A rope used in the sport of skipping.
The traditional uniform worn for Karate practice and competition.
A tool used for propelling a kayak.
A mask worn by kendo practitioners to protect the head.
A type of skateboard.
A small one- or two-person sled on which one sleds supine and feet-first.
A cape used by a matador in a bullfight.
A metal disk with an inscription or design, made to commemorate an event or awarded as a distinction to someone such as a soldier, athlete, or scholar.
A large funnel-shaped device for amplifying and directing the voice.

difficult.hint: A team sport played by two teams of eleven players on a rectangular field with goalposts at each end.
A Finnish rally driver turned politician and a Member of the European Parliament from 1999 to 2009.
A Brazilian racing driver who won the Formula One World Drivers' Championship in 1988, 1990 and 1991.
An American professional stock car driver and team owner, who raced from 1975 to 2001 in the former NASCAR Winston Cup Series.
A track and field event in which an athlete throws a heavy disc—called a discus—in an attempt to mark a farther distance than their competitors.
A sport in which individuals, pairs, or groups perform on figure skates on ice.
A track and field event where the javelin, a spear about 2.5 m (8 ft 2 in) in length, is thrown.
A Finnish former rally driver. He won 23 world rallies and four drivers' world championships, which were both records in their time.
A British racing driver currently competing in Formula One for Mercedes.
A Finnish former rally and rallycross driver. He is a two-time world champion in the World Rally Championship, winning the title in 2000 and 2002.
Codified systems and traditions of combat practiced for a number of reasons such as self-defense, military and law enforcement applications, competition, physical, mental and spiritual development.
An action sport that involves riding and performing tricks using a skateboard, as well as a recreational activity, an art form, an entertainment industry job, and a method of transportation.
A winter sport in which competitors aim to achieve the longest jump after descending from a specially designed ramp on their skis.
A retired Swedish rally driver. He made his international breakthrough in 1971.

A French professional rally, racing, and rallycross driver. He competed for the Citroën World Rally Team in the World Rally Championship (WRC) and is the most successful driver in WRC history, having won the world championship a record nine consecutive times.
A French rally driver, competing for the Toyota Gazoo Racing team in the World Rally Championship, who is teamed with co-driver Julien Ingrassia.
A Finnish retired rally driver, and the current team principal of the Toyota Gazoo Racing team in the World Rally Championship.
A water sport in which the rider, standing on a short board with foot bindings, is towed by a motorboat across its wake and especially up off the crest in order to perform aerial maneuvers.
A surface water sport in which an individual is pulled behind a boat or a cable ski installation over a body of water, skimming the surface on two skis or one ski.
The skill of riding, driving, steeple chasing or vaulting with horses.
A sport in which individuals, pairs, or groups perform on figure skates on ice.
An Olympic sport that comprises five different events; fencing, 200 m freestyle swimming, show jumping, and a final combined event of pistol shooting and a 3200 m cross-country run.
The sport of racing motorcycles.
The set of activities that involves ascending mountains.
A sport in which individuals or groups of five or more manipulate one or two pieces of apparatus: rope, hoop, ball, clubs, ribbon and freehand.
An action sport which involves riding and performing tricks using a skateboard.
A recreational activity and Olympic and Paralympic sport that involves descending a snow-covered slope while standing on a snowboard attached to a rider's feet.
A sport which includes athletic contests established on the skills of running, jumping, and throwing.
An athletic discipline in the modern Olympic programme in which the athlete attempts a single maximum-weight lift of a barbell loaded with weight plates.
A team sport played by two teams of eleven players on a rectangular field with goalposts at each end.
An Irish team sport. It is a form of football derived from traditional Irish ball games.
A full-contact sport played by two teams of thirteen players on a rectangular field.
A close-contact team sport that originated in England in the first half of the 19th century.
A form of skiing where skiers rely on their own locomotion to move across snow-covered terrain, rather than using ski lifts or other forms of assistance.
A skiing discipline comprising aerials, moguls, cross, half-pipe, slopestyle and big air as part of the Winter Olympics.
A winter sport in which athletes compete in cross-country skiing and ski jumping.
A winter sport in which competitors aim to achieve the longest jump after descending from a specially designed ramp on their skis.
A competitive form of ice skating in which the competitors race each other in travelling a certain distance on skates.
A hybrid form of swimming, dance, and gymnastics, consisting of swimmers performing a synchronized routine of elaborate moves in the water, accompanied by music.
A martial art and combat sport based on ground fighting and submission holds.
The use of progressive resistance exercise to control and develop one's musculature for aesthetic purposes.
An activity in which the participants cheer for their team as a form of encouragement.
A boat of a traditional design, typically decorated with a dragon's head and tail, used in the sport of dragon boat racing.
A horse race run on a racecourse or cross-country, in which runners are required to jump over hurdles.
A cavalry sport of ancient origin, and is one of only ten equestrian disciplines officially recognised by the International Equestrian Federation.
An annual men's multiple stage bicycle race primarily held in France, while also occasionally passing through nearby countries.
One of the four major championships in professional golf.
The oldest golf tournament in the world, and one of the most prestigious.
The annual championship series of Major League Baseball in North America, contested since 1903 between the American League champion team and the National League champion team.

The NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament, a single-elimination tournament played each spring in the United States, currently featuring 68 college basketball teams from the Division I level of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, to determine the national championship.
A piece of equipment used in the sport of badminton.
A large leather glove worn by baseball players in the field.
A type of helmet used to protect the head in cycling.
A small, hard ball used in cue sports, such as carom billiards, pool, and snooker.
A bounded table on which billiards-type games are played.
A target in the sport of bowling.
Cushioned gloves that fighters wear on their hands during boxing matches and practices.
A tool used for propelling a canoe.
A mallet used in the sport of croquet.
A mask worn by fencers to protect the head.
A type of ice skate used in the sport of figure skating.
A long, flexible rod used by fishermen to catch fish.
A protective helmet worn by football players.
The bar that athletes must clear in the high jump.
A disk used in the game of ice hockey.
